The '''behavioral analysis of child development''' originates from [[John B. Watson]]'s [[behaviorism]].<ref>Watson, J.B. (1926). What the nursery has to say about instincts. In C. Murchison (Eds.) ''Psychologies of 1925''. Worchester, MA: Clark University Press.</ref> Watson studied child development, looking specifically at development through conditioning (see [[Little Albert experiment]]). He helped bring a natural science perspective to child psychology by introducing objective research methods based on observable and measurable behavior. [[B.F. Skinner]] then further extended this model to cover [[operant conditioning]] and [[verbal behavior]]. Skinner was then able to focus these research methods on feelings and how those emotions can be shaped by a subject’s interaction with the environment.<ref>Skinner, B.F. (1974). ''About Behaviorism.'' Knopf</ref><ref>Skinner, B.F. (1953) ''Science and Human Behavior''. New York: The Free Press</ref> Sidney Bijou (1955) was the first to use this methodological approach extensively with children.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bijou |first=S.W. |year= 1955 |title=A systematic approach to an experimental analysis of young children |journal=Child Development |volume=26 |issue=3 |pages=161–168 |pmid=13261293 |doi=10.2307/1126106}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bijou |first=S.W. |year=1957 |title=Patterns of reinforcement and resistance to extinction in young children |journal=Child Development |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=47–54 |pmid=13404656 |doi=10.2307/1125999}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bijou |first=S.W. |year=1958 |title=Operant extinction after fixed-interval schedules with young children |journal=Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=25–29 |pmid=16811199 |pmc= 1403884 |doi=10.1901/jeab.1958.1-25}}</ref>
==History== In 1948, [[Sidney Bijou]] took a position as associate professor of psychology at the University of Washington and served as director of the university’s Institute of Child Development. Under his leadership, the Institute added a child development clinic, nursery school classrooms, and a research lab.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Morris|first=Edward K.|title=Sidney W. Bijou: The Illinois Years, 1965-1975|journal=Behavior Anal.|date=Fall 2008|volume=31|issue=2|pages=179–203|pmc=2591757|pmid=22478510}}</ref> Bijou began working with [[Donald M. Baer|Donald Baer]] in the Department of Human Development and Family Life at the [[University of Kansas]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Baer |first=D.M. |year=1993 |title=A brief, selective history of the Department of Human Development and Family Life at the University of Kansas: The early years |journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=569–572 |pmid=16795815 |pmc=1297894 |doi= 10.1901/jaba.1993.26-569}}</ref> applying [[behavior analytic]] principles to child development in an area referred to as "Behavioral Development" or "Behavior Analysis of Child Development".<ref>{{cite book |author1=Bijou, S.W. |author2=Baer, D.M. |year=1961 |title=Child Development: Vol. 1: a Systematic and Empirical Theory |publisher=Prentice-Hall |isbn=0-13-130377-5}}</ref> Skinner's behavioral approach and Kantor's interbehavioral approach were adopted in Bijou and Baer's model. They created a three-stage model of development (e.g., basic, foundational, and societal). Bijou and Baer looked at these socially determined stages, as opposed to organizing behavior into change points or cusps ([[behavioral cusp]]).<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bosch |first=S. |last2=Hixson |first2=M.D. |year=2004 |title=The Final Piece to a Complete Science of Behavior: Behavior Development and Behavioral Cusps |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=244–253}}</ref> In the behavioral model, development is considered a behavioral change. It is dependent on the kind of stimulus and the person’s behavioral and learning function.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Baer |first=D.M. |year=1982 |title=Behavior analysis and developmental psychology: Discussant comments |journal=Human Development |volume=25 |pages=357–361}}</ref> Behavior analysis in child development takes a mechanistic, contextual, and pragmatic approach.<ref>{{Cite journal |last= Morris |first=E.K. |year=1988 |title=Contextualism: The worldview of behavior analysis |journal=Journal of Experimental Child Psychology |volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=289–323 |doi=10.1016/0022-0965(88)90063-X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Schlinger |first=H.D. |year=2004 |title=The almost blank slate: Making a case for human nurture |journal=Skeptic |volume=11 |pages=34–43}}</ref>
From its inception, the behavioral model has focused on prediction and control of the developmental process.<ref>Baer, D.M. (1973). The control of developmental process: Why wait? In J.R. Nesselrode & H.W. Reese (Eds.) ''Life Span Developmental Psychology: Methodological Issues''. Oxford, England: Academic Press</ref><ref name="Schlinger, H.D. 1995">Schlinger, H.D., Jr. (1995). ''A Behavior Analytic View of Child Development''. NY: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers</ref> The model focuses on the analysis of a behavior and then synthesizes the action to support the original behavior.<ref>Catania, A.C. (1998). ''Learning'' (fourth edition). Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice-Hall, Inc.</ref> The model was changed after [[Richard J. Herrnstein]] studied the [[matching law]] of choice behavior developed by studying of reinforcement in the natural environment. More recently, the model has focused more on behavior over time and the way that behavioral responses become repetitive.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Morris |first=E.K. |last2=Hursch |first2=D.E. |year=1982 |title=Behavior analysis and developmental psychology: Metatheoretical considerations |journal=Human Development |volume=25 |pages=344–349}}</ref> it has become concerned with how behavior is selected over time and forms into stable patterns of responding.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Reese |first=H.W. |year=2005 |title=A Conceptual Analysis of Selectionism: Parts I and II. |journal=Behavioral Development Bulletin |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=8–16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Vyse |first=S. |year=2004 |title=Stability over time: Is behavior analysis a trait psychology? |journal=The Behavior Analyst |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=43–54}}</ref> A detailed history of this model was written by Pelaez.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Pelaez |year=1998 |title=Behavior analysis of development: History, theory, and research |journal=Mexican Journal of Behavior Analysis |volume=24 |pages=85–95}}</ref> In 1995, Henry D. Schlinger, Jr. provided the first behavior analytic text since Bijou and Baer comprehensively showed how behavior analysis—a natural science approach to human behavior—could be used to understand existing research in child development.<ref name= "Schlinger, H.D. 1995"/> In addition, the quantitative behavioral developmental model by Commons and Miller is the first behavioral theory and research to address notion similar to stage.<ref>''Behavioral Development Bulletin'', 13 (1)</ref>
==Research methods==
The methods used to analyze behavior in [[child development]] are based on several types of measurements. [[Single-subject research]] with a [[longitudinal study]] follow-up is a commonly-used approach. Current research is focused on integrating [[single-subject design]]s through meta-analysis to determine the effect sizes of behavioral factors in development. Lag sequential analysis has become popular for tracking the stream of behavior during observations. Group designs are increasingly being used. Model construction research involves [[latent growth modeling]] to determine developmental trajectories and [[structural equation modeling]]. [[Rasch model|Rasch analysis]] is now widely used to show sequentiality within a developmental trajectory.
A recent methodological change in the behavioral analytic theory is the use of observational methods combined with lag sequential analysis can determine [[reinforcement]] in the natural setting.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Snyder |first=J.J. |last2=Patterson |first2=G.R. |year=1986 |title=The effects of consequences on patterns of social interaction: A quasi-experimental approach to [[reinforcement]] in the natural environment |journal=Child Development |volume=57 |issue=5 |pages=1257–1268 |pmid=3769609 |doi=10.2307/1130448 |jstor=1130448}}</ref>
===Quantitative behavioral development===
The [[model of hierarchical complexity]] is a quantitative analytic theory of development. This model offers an explanation for why certain tasks are acquired earlier than others through developmental sequences and gives an explanation of the biological, cultural, organizational, and individual principles of performance.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Commons|first=M.L.|title=Formal, systematic, and metasystematic operations with a balance-beam task series: A reply to Kallio's claim of no distinct systematic stage|journal=Adult Development|year=1995|volume=2|issue=3|pages=193–199|doi=10.1007/bf02265717|display-authors=etal}}</ref> It quantifies the order of hierarchical complexity of a task based on explicit and mathematical measurements of behavior.
==Research==
===Contingencies, uncertainty, and attachment=== The behavioral model of [[Attachment theory|attachment]] recognizes the role of uncertainty in an infant and the child’s limited communication abilities. Contingent relationships are instrumental in the behavior analytic theory, because much emphasis is put on those actions that produce parents’ responses.<ref name="Cavell02">Cavell, T.A. & Strand, P.S. (2002). Parent-Based interventions for aggressive, antisocial children: Adapting to a bilateral lens. In L. Kuczynski (Ed.) ''Handbook of dynamics in parent-child relations''. (pp. 395–419). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.</ref><ref name="Gewirtz, J.L. 1991 pp. 123">Gewirtz, J.L. & Peláez-Nogueras, M. (1991). The attachment metaphor and the conditioning of infant separation protests. In J.L. Gewirtz & W.M. Kurtines (Eds.), ''Intersections with attachment''. (pp. 123–144). Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum</ref><ref>Patterson, G.R. (2002). The early development of coercive family processes. In J.B. Reid, G.R. Patterson & J. Snyder, J.J. (Eds.). ''Antisocial behavior in children and adolescents: A Developmental analysis and model for intervention''. APA Press</ref>
The importance of contingency appears to be highlighted in other developmental theories,<ref>Watson, J.S. (1979). Perception of contingency as a determinant of social responsiveness. In E.B. Thoman (Ed.), Origins of the infant's social responsiveness. In E.B. Thoman (Ed.) ''Origins of the infant's social responsiveness''. (pp. 33–64). Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum</ref> but the behavioral model recognizes that contingency must be determined by two factors:<ref>Gewirtz, J.L. & Boyd, E.F. (1977). Experiments on mother-infant interaction underlying mutual attachment acquisition: The infant conditions the mother. In T. Alloway, P. Plinger & L. Krames (Eds.). ''Attachment behavior''. (pp. 109–143). New York: Plenum Press</ref> the efficiency of the action and that efficiency compared to other tasks that the infant might perform at that point. Both infants and adults function in their environments by understanding these contingent relationships. Research has shown that contingent relationships lead to emotionally satisfying relationships.<ref name="Dunst 2007">{{Cite journal |last=Dunst |first=C.J. |last2=Raab |first2=M. |last3=Trivette |first3=C.M. |last4=Parkey |first4=C. |last5=Gatens |first5=M. |last6=Wilson |first6=L.L. French |last7=Hamby |first7=D.W. |year=2007 |title=Child and Adult Social-Emotional Benefits of Response-Contingent Child Learning Opportunities |url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ805542&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ805542 |journal=JEIBI |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=379–391}}</ref>
Since 1961, behavioral research has shown that there is relationship between the parents’ responses to separation from the infant and outcomes of a “stranger situation.”.<ref>Gewirtz, J.L. (1961). A learning analysis of the effects of normal stimulation, privation, and deprivation on the acquisition of social motivation and attachment. In B.M. Foss (Ed.), ''Determinants of infant behaviour''. (pp. 213–229). New York: Wiley.</ref> In a study done in 2000, six infants participated in a classic reversal design (see [[single-subject research]]) study that assessed infant approach rate to a stranger. If attention was based on stranger avoidance, the infant avoided the stranger. If attention was placed on infant approach, the infant approached the stranger.<ref>Gewirtz, J. & Pelaez-Nogueras, M. (2000). Infant emotions under the positive-reinforcer control of caregiver attention and touch. In J.C. Leslie & D. Blackman (Eds.), ''Issues in Experimental and Applied Analysis of Human Behavior''. (pp. 271–291). Reno, NV: Context Press</ref>
Recent meta-analytic studies of this model of attachment based on contingency found a moderate effect of contingency on attachment, which increased to a large effect size when the quality of reinforcement was considered.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kassow |first=D.Z. |last2=Dunst |first2=C.J. |year=2004 |title=Relationship between parental contingent-responsiveness and attachment outcomes |url=http://www.researchtopractice.info/bridges/bridges_vol2_no4.pdf |journal=Bridges |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=1–17}}</ref> Other research on contingency highlights its effect on the development of both pro-social and anti-social behavior.<ref name="Cavell02"/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wahler |first=R.G. |last2=Herring |first2=M. |last3=Edwards |first3=M. |year=2001 |title=[[Coregulation]] of balance between children's prosocial approaches and acts of compliance: A pathway to mother–child cooperation? |journal=Journal of Clinical Child Psychology |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=473–478 |pmid=11708235 |doi=10.1207/S15374424JCCP3004_04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wahler |first=R.G. |last2=Bellamy |first2=A. |year=1997 |title=Generating reciprocity with conduct problem children and their mothers: The effectiveness of compliance teaching and responsive parenting |journal=Journal of Social and Personal Relationships (Special issue: Reciprocity and Bidirectionality) |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=549–564 |doi=10.1177/0265407597144009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wahler |first=R.G. |last2=Smith |first2=G.G. |year=1999 |title=Effective parenting as the integration of lessons and dialogue |journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=135–149 |doi=10.1023/A:1022031716547}}</ref> These effects can also be furthered by training parents to become more sensitive to children’s behaviors,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dunst |first=C.J. |last2=Kassow |first2=D.Z. |year=2004 |title=Characteristics of interventions promoting parental sensitivity to child behavior |journal=Bridges |volume=2 |pages=1–17}}</ref> Meta-analytic research supports the notion that attachment is operant-based learning.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dunst |first=C.J. |last2=Kassow |first2=D.Z. |year=2008 |title=Caregiver Sensitivity, Contingent Social Responsiveness, and Secure Infant Attachment |journal=Journal of Early and Intensive Behavioral Intervention |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=40–56}}</ref>
An infant's sensitivity to contingencies can be affected by biological factors and environment changes. Studies show that being placed in erratic environments with few contingencies may cause a child to have conduct problems and may lead to depression. (see Behavioral Development and Depression below).<ref>Cairns, R.B. (1979). ''The analysis of social interaction: Methods, issues, and illustrations.'' Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum</ref><ref>Quay, H.C. (1987). Patterns of delinquent behavior. In H.C. Quay (Ed.). ''Handbook of Juvenile Delinquency''. (pp. 118–138). New York: Wiley</ref> Research continues to look at the effects of learning-based attachment on [[moral development]]. Some studies have shown that erratic use of contingencies by parents early in life can produce devastating long-term effects for the child.<ref>Commons, M.L. (1991). A comparison and synthesis of Kohlberg's cognitive developmental theories and Gewirtz's learning-developmental attachment theories. In J.L. Gewirtz & W.M. Kurtines (Eds.) ''Intersections with attachment''. Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Commons |first=M.L. |last2=Miller |first2=P.M. |year=2007 |title=How Early Negative Caregiving: Experiences Relate to Stage of Attachment |journal=Behavioral Development Bulletin |volume=13 |pages=14–17}}</ref>
===Motor development=== Since Watson developed the theory of behaviorism, behavior analysts have held that [[motor development]] represents a conditioning process. This holds that crawling, climbing, and walking displayed by infants represents conditioning of biologically innate [[reflexes]]. In this case, the reflex of stepping is the respondent behavior and these reflexes are environmentally conditioned through experience and practice. This position was criticized by maturation theorists. They believed that the stepping reflex for infants actually disappeared over time and was not "continuous". By working with a slightly different theoretical model, while still using operant conditioning, [[Esther Thelen]] was able to show that children's stepping reflex disappears as a function of increased physical weight. However, when infants were placed in water, that same stepping reflex returned.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Savelsbergh |first=G.J.P. |year=2005 |title=Discovery Of Motor Development: A Tribute To Esther Thelen |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=243–249}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Thelen |first=E. |last2=Fisher |first2=D.M. |year= 1982 |title=Newborn stepping: An explanation for a 'disappearing reflex{{'-}} |journal=Developmental Psychology |volume=18 |issue=5 |pages=760–775 |doi=10.1037/0012-1649.18.5.760}}</ref> This offered a model for the continuity of the stepping reflex and the progressive stimulation model for behavior analysts.
Infants [[relative deprivation|deprived]] of physical [[stimulation]] or the opportunity to respond were found to have delayed motor development.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dennis |first=W. |year=1960 |title=Causes of retardation among institutional children: Iran |journal=Journal of Genetic Psychology |volume=96 |pages=47–59 |pmid=13815945 |doi=10.1080/00221325.1960.10534274}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dennis |first=W. |last2=Najarian |first2=P. |year=1957 |title=Infant development under environmental handicap |journal=Psychological Monograph |volume=71 |issue=7 |pages=1–13 |doi=10.1037/h0093705}}</ref> Under conditions of extra stimulation, the motor behavior of these children rapidly improved.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sayegh |first=Y. |last2=Dennis |first2=W. |year=1965 |title=The effects of supplementary experience upon behavioral development of infants in institutions |journal=Child Development |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=81–90 |pmid=14296799 |doi=10.2307/1126782 |jstor=1126782}}</ref> Some research has shown that the use of a treadmill can be beneficial to children with motor delays including [[Down syndrome]] and cerebral palsy.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Masiello |first=T. |last2=Tucker |year=2006 |title=Influences of treadmill training on the motor development of infants with and without disabilities |url=http://www.researchtopractice.info/bridges/bridges_vol4_no5.pdf |journal=Bridges |volume=4 |issue=5 |pages=1–17}}</ref> Research on opportunity to respond and the building of motor development continues today.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Cautilli |first=J.D. |last2=Dziewolska |first2=H. |year=2005 |title=A Brief Report: Can Contingent Imitation Reinforce Truck Lifting In A Three-Month-Old Infant? |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=229–234}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dziewolska |first=H. |last2= Cautilli |first2=J.D. |year= 2006 |title=The Effects of a Motor Training Package on Minimally Assisted Standing Behavior in a Three-Month-Old Infant |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=111–124}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Cautilli |first=J.D. |last2=Dziewolska |first2=H. |year=2006 |title=Brief Report: The Use of Opportunity to Respond and Practice to increase efficiency of the stepping reflex in a five-month-old infant |url= |journal=Behavior Analyst Today |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=538–547}}</ref>
The behavioral development model of motor activity has produced a number of techniques, including [[operant]]-based [[biofeedback]] to facilitate development with success. Some of the stimulation methods such as operant-based biofeedback have been applied as treatment to children with [[cerebral palsy]] and even spinal injury successfully.<ref>Ince, L.; Brucker, B. & Alba A. (1977): Behavioral techniques applied to the care of patients with spinal cord injuries. In J. Kamiya, T.X. Barber, N.E. Miller, D. Shapiro & J. Stoyva (Eds.) ''Biofeedback and Self-control''. Chicago, IL: Alpine, 515–523.</ref><ref>Brucker B. (1983): Spinal cord injuries. In Burish and Bradley (Ed.) ''Coping with Chronic Disease: Research and Applications''. New York: Academic Press, 285–311.</ref><ref>Brucker B. (1984): Biofeedback in rehabilitation. In Golden (Ed.) ''Current Topics in Rehabilitation Psychology''. San Diego, California: Grune and Stratton, 173–199</ref><ref>Brucker, B.; & Ince, L. (1979): Biofeedback as an experimental treatment for postural hypotension in a patient with a spinal cord lesion. In J. Stoyva, J. Kamiya, T.X. Barber, N.E. Miller & D. Shapiro (Eds.). ''Biofeedback and Self Control''. Hawthorne, NY: Aldine, 557–561.</ref> Brucker's group demonstrated that specific operant conditioning-based biofeedback procedures can be effective in establishing more efficient use of remaining and surviving central nervous system cells after injury or after birth complications (like cerebral palsy).<ref>Brucker, B. (1980): Biofeedback and rehabilitation. In L.P. Ince (Ed.) ''Behavioral Psychology in Rehabilitation Medicine: Clinical Applications''. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 188–217.</ref><ref>Miller, N. & Brucker, B. (1981): A learned visceral response apparently independent of skeletal ones in patients paralyzed by spinal lesions. In D. Shapiro, J. Stoyva, J. Kamiya, T.X. Barber, N.E. Miller & G.E. Schwartz (Eds.). ''Biofeedback and behavioral medicine''. Hawthorne, NY: Aldine, 355–372</ref> While such methods are not a cure and gains tend to be in the moderate range, they do show ability to enhance functioning.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Brucker |first=B.S. |last2=Bulaeva |first2=N.V. |year=1996 |title=Biofeedback effect on electromyography responses in patients with spinal cord injury |journal=Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation |volume=77 |issue=2 |pages=133–137 |pmid=8607736 |doi=10.1016/S0003-9993(96)90157-4}}</ref>
===Imitation and verbal behavior=== Behaviorists have studied verbal behavior since the 1920s.<ref>Watson, J.B. (1924). Talking and thinking. In J.B Watson's ''Behaviorism''. Norton, New York.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kantor |first= J.R. |year=1929 |title=Can psychology contribute to the study of linguistics? |journal=The Monist |volume=38 |pages=630–648 |doi=10.5840/monist19283846}}</ref><ref>Weiss, A.P. (1929). The language responses. In A.P. Weiss's (Ed.) ''A theoretical basis of human behavior''. Adams, Columbus, Oh</ref> E.A. Esper (1920) studied associative models of language,<ref>Esper, E.A. (1925). A technique for the experimental investigation of associative inference in artificial linguistic systems. Language Monographs No. 1</ref> which has evolved into the current language interventions of matrix training and recombinative generalization.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Mineo |first=D.A. |last2=Goldstein |first2=H. |year=1990 |title=Generalized learning of receptive and expressive action–object responses by language delayed preschoolers |journal=Journal of Speech and Hearing Disorders |volume=55 |issue=4 |pages=665–678 |pmid=2232747}}</ref><ref>Wetherby, B. (1978). Miniature language and the functional analysis of verbal behavior. In R. Schiefelbusch (Ed.), ''Bases of language intervention''. (pp. 397–448). Baltimore: University Park Press.</ref> Skinner (1957) created a comprehensive taxonomy of language for speakers. Baer, along with Zettle and Haynes (1989), provided a developmental analysis of rule-governed behavior for the listener.<ref name="Skinner57">Skinner, B.F. (1957). ''Verbal Behavior''. New York: Appleton</ref> and for the listener Zettle and Hayes (1989) with Don Baer providing a developmental analysis of rule-governed behavior.<ref>Riegler, H.C. & Baer, D.M. (1989). A developmental analysis of rule-following. In H.W. Reese (Ed.) ''Advances in child development and behavior''. (Vol. 21). San Diego: Academic Press.</ref> According to Skinner, language learning depends on environmental variables, which can be mastered by a child through imitation, practice, and selective [[reinforcement]] including automatic reinforcement.
[[B.F. Skinner]] was one of the first psychologists to take the role of imitation in verbal behavior as a serious mechanism for acquisition.<ref name="Skinner57"/> He identified echoic behavior as one of his basic verbal operants, postulating that verbal behavior was learned by an infant from a verbal community. Skinner's account takes verbal behavior beyond an intra-individual process to an inter-individual process. He defined verbal behavior as "behavior reinforced through the mediation of others".<ref>Skinner, B.F. (1957), page 4</ref> [[Noam Chomsky]] refuted Skinner’s assumptions.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Chomsky |first=N. |last2=Skinner |first2=B.F. |year=1959 |title=Review of Skinner's Verbal Behavior |journal=Language |volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=26–58 |doi=10.2307/411334 |jstor= 411334}}</ref>
In the behavioral model, the child is prepared to contact the contingencies to "join" the listener and speaker.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Greer |first=R.D. |last2=Keohane |first2=D. |year=2006 |title=The Evolution of Verbal Behavior in Children |journal=Slp- Aba |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=111–140}}</ref> At the very core, verbal episodes involve the rotation of the roles as speaker and listener.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Reese |first=H.W. |year=2004 |title=Private Speech and Other Forms of Self-Communication |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=182–189}}</ref><ref>Skinner (1957). ''Verbal Behavior''. Croft</ref> These kinds of exchanges are called conversational units<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ross |first=D.E. |last2= Nuzzolo |first2=R. |last3=Stolfi |first3=L. |last4=Natarelli |first4=S. |year=2006 |title=Effects of Speaker Immersion on the Spontaneous Speaker Behavior of Preschool Children with Communication Delays |journal=JEIBI |url= |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=135–145}}</ref> and have been the focus of research at Columbia's communication disorders department.
Conversational units is a measure of socialization because they consist of verbal interactions in which the exchange is reinforced by both the speaker and the listener.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Greer |first=R.D. |last2=Ross |first2=D.E. |year=2004 |title=Verbal behavior analysis: A program of research in the induction and expansion of complex verbal behavior |journal=Journal of Early Intensive Behavioral Intervention |url= |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=141–165}}</ref> H.C. Chu (1998) demonstrated contextual conditions for inducing and expanding conversational units between children with autism and non-handicapped siblings in two separate experiments.<ref name="Chu98">Chu, H.C. (1998). A comparison of verbal-behavior and social-skills approaches for development of social interaction skills and concurrent reduction of aberrant behaviors of children with developmental disabilities in the context of matching theory. (Doctoral dissertation, Columbia University, 1998). Abstract from: UMI Proquest Digital Dissertations [on-line]. Dissertations Abstracts Item: AAT 9838900.</ref> The acquisition of conversational units and the expansion of verbal behavior decrease incidences of physical "aggression" in the Chu study<ref name="Chu98"/> and several other reviews suggest similar effects.<ref name="Patterson02">{{Cite journal |last=Patterson |first=G.R. |year=2002 |title=Etiology and Treatment of Child and Adolescent Antisocial Behavior |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=133–145}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Cautilli |first=J. |last2=Tillman |first2=T.C. |year=2004 |title=Evidence Based Practice in the Home and School to Help Educate the Socially Maladjusted Child |url= |journal=JEIBI |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=28–35}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bevill-Davis |first=A. |last2=Clees |first2=T.J. |last3=Gast |first3=D.L. |year=2004 |title=Correspondence Training: A Review of the Literature |url= |journal= JEIBI |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=14–28}}</ref> The joining of the listener and speaker progresses from listener speaker rotations with others as a likely precedent for the three major components of speaker-as-own listener—say so correspondence, self-talk conversational units, and naming.<ref>Greer, R.D. & Speckman, J.M. (in press). The Integration of Speaker and Listener Responses: A Theory of the Development of Verbal Behavior. ''The Psychological Record''.</ref>
===Development of self=== Robert Kohelenberg and Mavis Tsai (1991) created a behavior analytic model accounting for the development of one’s “self”.<ref>Kohlenberg, R. & Tsai, M. (1991)</ref> Their model proposes that verbal processes can be used to form a stable sense of who we are through behavioral processes such as [[stimulus control]]. Kohlenberg and Tsai developed [[functional analytic psychotherapy]] to treat psychopathological disorders arising from the frequent invalidations of a child’s statements such that “I” does not emerge. Other behavior analytic models for personality disorders exist.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Nelson-Gray |first=R.O. |last2=Mitchell |first2=J.T. |last3=Kimbrel |first3=N.A. |last4=Hurst |first4=R.M. |year=2007 |title=The Development and Maintenance of Personality Disorders: A Behavioral Perspective |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=443–445}}</ref> They trace out the complex biological–environmental interaction for the development of avoidant and borderline personality disorders. They focus on [[Reinforcement sensitivity theory]], which states that some individuals are more or less sensitive to reinforcement than others. Nelson-Grey views problematic response classes as being maintained by reinforcing consequences or through rule governance.
===Socialization=== Over the last few decades, studies have supported the idea that contingent use of [[reinforcement]] and [[punishment]] over extended periods of time lead to the development of both pro-social and anti-social behaviors.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Eisenberg, N. |author2=Wolchik, S.A. |author3=Goldberg, L. |author4=Engel, I. |year=1992 |title=Parental values, reinforcement, and young children's prosocial behavior: a longitudinal study |journal=J Genet Psychol |volume=153 |issue=1 |pages=19–36 |pmid=1645156 |doi=10.1080/00221325.1992.10753699}}</ref><ref name="Snyder, J.J.; Patterson, G.R. 1995 371–91">{{cite journal |author1=Snyder, J.J. |author2=Patterson, G.R. |year=1995 |title=Individual differences in social aggression: a test of a reinforcement model of socialization in the natural environment |journal=Behav Ther |volume=26 |issue=2 |pages=371–91 |doi=10.1016/S0005-7894(05)80111-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Patterson, G.R. |year=2002 |title=Etiology and treatment of child and adolescent antisocial behavior |journal=Behav Analyst Today |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=133–45 |url=http://behavior-analyst-today.com/VOL-3/BAT-3-2.pdf |type = PDF}}</ref> However research has shown that reinforcement is more effective than punishment when teaching behavior to a child. It has also been shown that modeling is more effective than “preaching” in developing pro-social behavior in children.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bryan |first=J.H. |last2=Walbek |first2=N.H. |year=1970 |title=Impact of words and deeds concerning altruism upon children |journal=Child Development |volume=41 |issue=3 |pages=747–759 |doi=10.2307/1127221 |jstor=1127221}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bryan |first=J.H. |last2=Walbek |first2=N. |year=1970 |title=Preaching and practicing generosity: Children's action and reaction |journal=Child Development |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=329–353 |doi=10.2307/1127035 |jstor=1127035}}</ref> Rewards have also been closely studied in relation to the development of social behaviors in children. The building of self-control, empathy, and cooperation has all implicated rewards as a successful tactic, while sharing has been strongly linked with reinforcement.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Barry |first=L.M. |last2=Haraway |first2=D.L. |year=2005 |title=Self-Management and ADHD: A Literature Review |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=48–64}}</ref><ref>Maccoby, E.M. (1968). The development of moral values and behavior in childhood. In J.A. Clausen's (Ed). ''Socialization and Society''. Little Brown Books: Boston</ref><ref>Aronfreed, J. (1968). ''Conduct and conscience: The socializing of internalized control of overt behavior''. New York: Academic Press</ref><ref>Aronfreed, J. (1970). The socialization of altruistic and sympathetic behavior: Some theoretical and experimental analysis. In J. Macauley & L. Berkowitz (Eds.) ''Altruism and helping behavior''. New York: Academic Press.</ref>
The development of social skills in children is largely affected in that classroom setting by both teachers and peers. Reinforcement and punishment play major roles here as well. Peers frequently reinforce each other’s behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Charlesworth |first=R. |last2=Hartup |first2=W.W. |year=1967 |title=Positive social reinforcement in the nursery school per group |journal=Child Development |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages= 993–1002 |pmid=5583075 |doi=10.2307/1127097 |jstor=1127097}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Furman |first=W. |last2=Masters |first2=J.C. |year=1980 |title=Affective consequences of social reinforcement, punishment, and neutral behavior |journal=Developmental Psychology |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=100–104 |doi=10.1037/0012-1649.16.2.100}}</ref> One of the major areas that teachers and peers influence is sex-typed behavior, while peers also largely influence modes of initiating interaction, and aggression.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lamb |first=M.E. |last2=Easterbrooks |first2=M.A. |last3=Holden |first3=G.W. |year=1980 |title=Reinforcement and punishment among preschoolers: Characteristics, effects, and correlates |journal=Child Development |volume=51 |issue=4 |pages=1230–1236 |doi=10.2307/1129565 |jstor=1129565}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lamb |first=M.E. |last2=Roopnarine |first2=J.L. |year=1979 |title=Peer influences on sex-role development in preschoolers |journal=Child Development |volume=50 |issue=4 |pages=1219–1222 |doi=10.2307/1129353 |jstor=1129353}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Leiter |first=M.P. |year=1977 |title=A study of reciprocity in preschool play groups |journal=Child Development |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=1288–1295 |doi= 10.2307/1128486 |jstor=1128486}}</ref><ref>Patterson, G.R.; Littman, R.A. & Bricker, W. (1967). Assertive behavior in children: A step toward a theory of aggression. ''Monographs of the Society for Research in Child Development'', 32, (5, Serial No. 113).</ref> Peers are more likely to punish cross-gender play while at the same time reinforcing play specific to gender. .<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fagot |first=Beverly I. |last2=Patterson |first2=Gerald R. |title=An in vivo analysis of reinforcing contingencies for sex-role behaviors in the preschool child. |journal=Developmental Psychology |volume=1 |issue=5 |pages=563–568 |year=1969 |doi=10.1037/h0027965}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lamb |first=M.E. |last2=Roopnarine |first2=J.L. |year=1979 |title=Peer influences on sex role development in preschoolers |journal=Child Development |volume=50 |issue=4 |pages=1219–1222 |doi=10.2307/1129353 |jstor=1129353}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lamb |first=M.E. |last2=Easterbrooks |first2=M.A. |last3=Holden |first3=G. |year=1980 |title=Reinforcement and punishment among preschoolers: Characteristics and Corrales |journal=Child Development |volume=51 |issue=4 |pages=1230–1236 |doi=10.2307/1129565 |jstor=1129565}}</ref> Some studies found that teachers were more likely to reinforce dependent behavior in females.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Serbin |first=L.O'Leary |last2= Kent |first2=R. |last3=Tonick |first3=I. |last4=Tonick |first4=I.J. |year=1973 |title=A comparison of teacher responses to pre-academic and problem behavior of boys and girls |journal=Child Development |volume=44 |issue=4 |pages=796–804 |pmid=4751301 |doi=10.2307/1127726 |jstor=1127726}}</ref>
Behavioral principles have also been researched in emerging peer groups, focusing on status.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Coie |first=J.D. |last2=Kupersmidt |first2=J.B. |year=1983 |title=A Behavioral Analysis of Emerging Social Status in Boys' Groups. |journal=Child Development |volume=54 |issue=6 |pages=1400–1416 |doi=10.2307/1129803 |jstor=1129803}}</ref> Research shows that it takes different social skills to enter groups than it does to maintain or build one’s status in groups. Research also suggests that neglected children are the least interactive and aversive, yet remain relatively unknown in groups. Children suffering from social problems do see an improvement in social skills after [[behavior therapy]] and [[behavior modification]] (see [[applied behavior analysis]]). Modeling has been successfully used to increase participation by shy and withdrawn children.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Jakibuchuk |first=Z. |last2=Smeriglio |first2=V.L. |year=1976 |title=The influence of symbolic modeling on the social behavior of preschool children with low levels of social responsiveness |journal=Child Development |volume=47 |issue=3 |pages=838–841 |doi=10.2307/1128203 |jstor=1128203}}</ref> Shaping of socially desirable behavior through [[positive reinforcement]] seems to have some of the most positive effects in children experiencing social problems.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/h0033226 |author=O'Connor, R.D. |year=1972 |title=Relative efficacy of modeling, shaping, and the combined procedure for the modification of social withdrawal |journal=Journal of Abnormal Psychology |volume=79 |issue=3 |pages=327–334 |pmid=5033375}}</ref>
===Anti-social behavior=== In the development of [[anti-social behavior]], [[etiology|etiological models]] for anti-social behavior show considerable correlation with [[negative reinforcement]] and response matching (see [[matching law]]).<ref name= "Patterson02"/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Snyder |first=J. |last2=Stoolmiller |first2=M. |last3=Patterson |first3=G.R. |last4=Schrepferman |first4=L. |last5=Oeser |first5=J. |last6=Johnson |first6=K. |last7= Soetaert |first7=D. |year=2003 |title=The Application of Response Allocation Matching to Understanding Risk Mechanisms in Development: The Case of Young Children's Deviant Talk and Play, and Risk for Early-Onset Antisocial Behavior |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=435–453}}</ref> [[Aversives|Escape conditioning]], through the use of coercive behavior, has a powerful effect on the development and use of future anti-social tactics. The use of anti-social tactics during conflicts can be negatively reinforced and eventually seen as functional for the child in moment to moment interactions.<ref name="Snyder, J.J.; Patterson, G.R. 1995 371–91"/> Anti-social behaviors will also develop in children when imitation is reinforced by social approval. If approval is not given by teachers or parents, it can often be given by peers. An example of this is swearing. Imitating a parent, brother, peer, or a character on TV, a child may engage in the anti-social behavior of swearing. Upon saying it they may be reinforced by those around them which will lead to an increase in the anti-social behavior. The role of [[stimulus control]] has also been extensively explored in the development of anti-social behavior.<ref>Patterson, G.R.; Reid, J.B. & Eddy, J.M. (2002). A brief history of the Oregon model. In J.B. Reid, G.R. Patterson & J. Snyder (Eds.) ''Antisocial behavior in children and adolescents: A developmental analysis and model for interventions''. APA Press</ref> Recent behavioral focus in the study of anti-social behavior has been a focus on rule-governed behavior. While correspondence for saying and doing has long been an interest for behavior analysts in normal development and typical socialization, recent conceptualizations have been built around families that actively train children in anti-social rules, as well as children who fail to develop rule control.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Osnes |first=P.G. |last2=Adelinis |first2=J. |year=2005 |title=Correspondence Training, Rule Governance, Generalization, and Stimulus Control: Connections or Disconnections? |journal=Behavioral Development Bulletin |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=48–55}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Bevill-Davis Alicia |author2=Clees Tom J. |author3=Gast David L. |year=2004 |title= Correspondence Training: A Review of the Literature |journal=JEIBI |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=14–27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Peleaz |first=M. |last2=Moreno |first2=R. |year=1998 |title=A taxonomy of rules and their correspondence in rule governed behavior |journal=Mexican Journal of Behavior Analysis |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=197–214}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Snyder |first=J.J. |last2=McEachern |first2=A. |last3=Schrepferman |first3=L. |last4=Zettle |first4=R. |last5=Johnson |first5=K. |last6= Swink |first6=N. |last7=McAlpine |first7=C. |year=2006 |title=Rule-Governance, Correspondence Training, and Discrimination Learning: A Developmental Analysis of Covert Conduct Problems |journal=Slp-Aba |volume= 1 |issue=1 |pages=43–65}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Barry |first=L.M. |last2=Haraway |first2=D.L. |year=2005 |title=Behavioral Self-Control Strategies for Young Children |url= |journal=JEIBI |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=79–89}}</ref>
===Developmental depression with origins in childhood=== Behavioral theory of [[Depression (mood)|depression]] was outlined by [[Charles Ferster]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ferster |first=C.B. |year=1973 |title=A functional analysis of depression |journal=American Psychologist |volume=28 |issue=10 |pages=857–870 |pmid=4753644 |doi=10.1037/h0035605}}</ref> A later revision was provided by Peter Lewisohn and Hyman Hops. Hops continued the work on the role of [[negative reinforcement]] in maintaining depression with Anthony Biglan.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hops |first=H. |year=1992 |title=Parental depression and child behaviour problems: Implications for behavioural family intervention |journal= Behavior Change |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=126–138}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hops |first=H. |last2=Biglan |first2=A. |last3=Sherman |first3=L. Arhr |last4=Freidman |first4=L. |last5=Osteen |first5=V. |last6=Osteen |first6=V. |year=1987 |title=Home observation of family interactions of depressed woman |journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=341–346 |pmid=3597946 |doi=10.1037/0022-006X.55.3.341}}</ref><ref>Biglan, A.; Hops, H. & Sherman, L. (1988). Coercive family processes and maternal depression. In R.D. Peters & R.J. McMahon (Eds.) ''Social learning and systems approaches to marriage and family''. (pp. 72–103). New York: Brunner/Mazel.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Biglan |first=A. |last2=Rothlind |first2=J. |last3=Hops |first3=H. |last4=Sherman |first4=L. |year=1989 |title=Impact of distressed and aggressive behavior |journal=Journal of Abnormal Psychology |volume=98 |issue=3 |pages=218–228 |pmid=2768656 |doi=10.1037/0021-843X.98.3.218}}</ref> Additional factors such as the role of loss of contingent relations through extinction and punishment were taken from early work of Martin Seligman. The most recent summary and conceptual revisions of the behavioral model was provided by Johnathan Kanter.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kanter |first=J.W. |last2=Cautilli |first2=J.D. |last3=Busch |first3=A.M. |last4=Baruch |first4=D.E. |year=2005 |title=Toward a Comprehensive Functional Analysis of Depressive Behavior: Five Environmental Factors and a Possible Sixth and Seventh |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=65–74}}</ref> The standard model is that depression has multiple paths to develop. It can be generated by five basic processes, including: lack or loss of [[positive reinforcement]],<ref>In addition to loss of reinforcement, the loss of contingency between behavior and reinforcement can also lead to depression</ref> direct positive or negative reinforcement for depressive behavior, lack of rule-governed behavior or too much rule-governed behavior, and/or too much environmental [[punishment]]. For children, some of these variables could set the pattern for lifelong problems. For example, a child whose depressive behavior functions for [[negative reinforcement]] by stopping fighting between parents could develop a lifelong pattern of depressive behavior in the case of conflicts. Two paths that are particularly important are (1) lack or loss of reinforcement because of missing necessary skills at a developmental cusp point or (2) the failure to develop adequate rule-governed behavior. For the latter, the child could develop a pattern of always choosing the short-term small immediate reward (i.e., escaping studying for a test) at the expense of the long-term larger reward (passing courses in middle school). The treatment approach that emerged from this research is called [[behavioral activation]].
In addition, use of positive reinforcement has been shown to improve symptoms of depression in children.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Rawson |first=H.E. |last2=Tabb |first2=L.C. |year=1993 |title=Effects of therapeutic intervention on childhood depression |journal=Child and Adolesent Social Work Journal |volume=10 |pages=39–53}}</ref> Reinforcement has also been shown to improve the self-concept in children with depression comorbid with learning difficulties.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Rawson |first=H.E. |last2=Cassady |first2=J.C. |year=1995 |title=Effects of therapeutic intervention on self-concepts of children with learning disabilities |journal=Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=19–31 |doi=10.1007/BF01876137}}</ref> Rawson and Tabb (1993) used reinforcement with 99 students (90 males and 9 females) aged from 8 to 12 with behavior disorders in a residential treatment program and showed significant reduction in depression symptoms compared to the control group.
===Cognitive behavior=== As children get older, direct control of contingencies is modified by the presence of rule-governed behavior.<ref>Kendler, H. & Kendler, T. (1975). From discrimination learning to cognitive development: A neobehavioristic odyessey. In W.K. Estes (Ed.) ''Handbook of learning and cognitive processes'' (Vol 1). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawerence Erlbaum Associates.</ref> Rules serve as an establishing operation and set a motivational stage as well as a discrimintative stage for behavior.<ref name="Schlinger, H.D. 1995"/> While the size of the effects on intellectual development are less clear, it appears that stimulation does have a facilitative effect on intellectual ability.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dunst |first=C.J. |last2=Raab |first2=M. |last3=Wilson |first3=L.L. |last4=Parkey |first4=C. |year=2007 |title=Relative Efficiency Of Stimulation |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=8 |issue=2 |pages=226–236}}</ref> However, it is important to be sure not to confuse the enhancing effect with the initial causal effect.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Rondal |first=J.A. |last2=Docquier |first2=L. |year=2006 |title=Maternal Speech To Children With Down Syndrome: An Update |url= |journal=Slp-Aba |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=218–226}}</ref> Some data exists to show that children with developmental delays take more learning trials to acquire in material.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hutto |first=M. |year=2003 |title=Latency to learn in contingency studies of young children with disabilities or developmental delays |url=http://www.researchtopractice.info/bridges/bridges_vol1_no5.pdf |journal=Bridges |volume=1 |issue= 5 |pages=1–16}}</ref>
===Learned units and developmental retardation=== Behavior analysts have spent considerable time measuring learning in both the classroom and at home. In these settings, the role of a lack of stimulation has often been evidenced in the development of mild and moderate mental retardation.<ref>Bijou, S.W. (1966). A functional analysis of retarded development. In N.R. Ellis (Ed.) ''International Review of Research in Mental Retardation''. NY: Academic Press.</ref> Recent work has focused on a model of "developmental retardation,".<ref>Greenwood, C.R.; Hart, B.; Walker, D. & Risley, T. (1994). The opportunity to respond and academic performance revisited: A behavioral theory of developmental retardation and its prevention. In R. Gardener, D.M. Sainato, J.O. Cooper, T.E. Heron, W.L. Heward, J. Eshleman & T.A. Grossi (Eds.) ''Behavior analysis in education: Focus on measurably superior instruction''. (pp. 161–171) Pacific Grove, CA: Brookes-Cole</ref> an area that emphasizes cumulative environmental effects and their role in developmental delays. To measure these developmental delays, subjects are given the opportunity to respond, defined as the instructional antecedent, and success is signified by the appropriate response and/or fluency in responses.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Greenwood |first=Ward |last2=Luze |year=2003 |title=The Early Communication Indicator (ECI) for Infants and Toddlers: What It Is, Where It's Been, and Where It Needs to Go |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=383–392}}</ref> Consequently, the learned unit is identified by the opportunity to respond in addition to given reinforcement.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Greer |first=D. |last2=Keohane |first2=D. |last3=Healy |year=2002 |title=Quality and Comprehensive Applications of Behavior Analysis to Schooling |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=120–132}}</ref>
One study employed this model by comparing students' time of instruction was in affluent schools to time of instruction in lower income schools. Results showed that lower income schools displayed approximately 15 minutes less instruction than more affluent schools due to disruptions in [[classroom management]] and [[behavior management]]. Altogether, these disruptions culminated into two years worth of lost instructional time by grade 10.<ref>{{Cite journal |last= Greenwood |first=C.R. |last2=Carta |first2=J.J. |last3=Hart |first3=B. |last4=Kamps |first4=D. |last5=Terry |first5=D. |last6=Delquardi |first6=J.C. |last7=Walker |first7=D. |last8=Risley |first8=T.R. |last9= Risley |first9=T. |last10=Delquadri |first10=Joseph C. |year=1992 |title=Out of the laboratory and into the community: Twenty-six years of applied behavior analysis at Juniper Gardens Children Center |journal=American Psychologist |volume=47 |issue=11 |pages=1464–1474 |pmid=1482007 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.47.11.1464|display-authors=8 }}</ref> The goal of behavior analytic research is to provide methods for reducing the overall number of children who fall into the retardation range of development by [[behavioral engineering]].<ref>Bijou, S.W. (1983). The prevention of mild and moderate retarded development. In F.J. Menolascino, R. Neman & J.A. Stark (Eds.) ''Curative aspects of mental retardation: Biomedical and behavioral advances''. (pp. 223–241). Baltimore: Brookes.</ref>
Hart and Risely (1995, 1999) have completed extensive research on this topic as well.<ref>Hart, B. & Risley, T.R. (1995). ''Meaningful differences in the everyday experience of young American children''. Baltimore: Brookes</ref><ref>Hart, B. & Risley, T.R. (1999). ''The social world of children learning to talk''. Baltimore: Brookes</ref> These researchers measured the rates of parent communication with children of the ages of 2–4 years and correlated this information with the IQ scores of the children at age 9. Their analyses revealed that higher parental communication with younger children was positively correlated with higher IQ in older children, even after controlling for race, class, and socio-economic status. Additionally, they concluded a significant change in IQ scores required intervention with at-risk children for approximately 40 hours per week.
===Class formation=== The formation of class-like behavior has also been a significant aspect in the behavioral analysis of development. .<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Zentall |first=T.R. |last2=Galizio |first2=M. |last3=Critchfield |first3=T.S. |year=2002 |title=Categorization, concept learning, and behavior analysis: An introduction |journal=Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior |volume=78 |issue=3 |pages=237–248 |pmid=12507002 |pmc=1284898 |doi=10.1901/jeab.2002.78-237}}</ref> This research has provided multiple explanations to the development and formation of class-like behavior, including primary [[stimulus generalization]],<ref>Goldiamond, I. (1966). Perception, language, and conceptualization rules. In B. Kleinmutz (Ed.) ''Carnegie Institute of Technology Annual Symposium on Cognition''. John Wiley & Sons, New York.</ref><ref>Becker, W.C. (1971). Teaching concepts and operations, or how to make kids smart. In W.C. Becker (Ed.) ''An empirical basis for changing education''. Science research associates. Palo Alto, CA.</ref> an analysis of abstraction,<ref name="Skinner57"/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Herrnstein |first=R. |year=1990 |title=Levels of stimulus control: A. functional approach |journal=Cognition |volume=37 |issue=1–2 |pages=133–166 |pmid=2269005 |doi=10.1016/0010-0277(90)90021-B}}</ref><ref>Quine, W.V.O. (1953). ''From a logical point of view''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.</ref><ref>Quine, W.V.O. (1960). ''[[Word and Object]]''. Cambridge. MA: MIT Press.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hawkins |first=A.S. |year=1964 |title=Verbal identification of stimulus components in ambiguously named compounds |journal=Journal of Experimental Child Psychology |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=227–240 |doi=10.1016/0022-0965(64)90038-4}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1037/h0025778 |last=Steiner |first=T.E. |last2=Sobel |first2=R. |year=1968 |title=Intercomponent association formation during paired-associate training with compound stimuli |journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology |volume=77 |issue=2 |pages=275–280 |pmid=5655120}}</ref> [[relational frame theory]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Blackledge |year=2003 |title=An Introduction to Relational Frame Theory: Basics and Applications |url=http://institutoact.es/descargas/b04/b0415.pdf | format = PDF |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=421–430}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Barnes-Holmes |first=Yvonne |last2=McHugh |first2= Louise |last3=Barnes-Holmes |first3=Dermot |year=2004 |title=Perspective-Taking and Theory of Mind: A Relational Frame Account |url= |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=15–25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hayes |first=S.C. |last2=Hayes |first2=L.J. |year=1992 |title=Verbal relations and the evolution of behavior analysis |journal=American Psychologist |volume=47 |issue=11 |pages=1383–1395 |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.47.11.1383}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Roche |first=B |last2=Barnes-Holmes |first2=Y |last3=Barnes-Holmes |first3=D |last4=Stewart |first4=I |last5=O'Hora |first5=D. |year=2002 |title=Relational Frame Theory: A new paradigm for the analysis of social behavior |journal=The Behavior Analyst |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=75–91|pmid=22478379 |pmc=2731595 }}</ref> stimulus class analysis (sometimes referred to as recombinative generalization),<ref>Esper, E.A. (1925). A technique for the experimental investigation of associative inference in artificial linguistic systems. ''Language Monographs'' No. 1.</ref><ref>Wetherby, B. (1978). Miniature language and the functional analysis of verbal behavior. In R. Schiefelbusch (Ed.) ''Bases of language intervention''. (pp. 397–448). Baltimore: University Park Press.</ref> stimulus equivalence,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sidman |first=M. |year=2000 |title=Equivalence relations and the reinforcement contingency |journal=Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior |volume=74 |issue=1 |pages=127–146 |pmid=10966100 |pmc=1284788 |doi=10.1901/jeab.2000.74-127}}</ref> and response class analysis.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Krasner |first=L. |year=1958 |title=Studies of conditioning of verbal behavior |journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=55 |issue=3 |pages=148–170 |pmid=13542700 |doi=10.1037/h0040492}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1080/00221309.1959.9710241 |last= Salzinger |first=K. |year=1959 |title=Experimental manipulation of verbal behavior: A review |journal=Journal of General Psychology |volume=61 |issue=1 |pages=65–94 |pmid=14441175}}</ref><ref>Salzinger, K. (1967). The problem of response class in verbal behavior. In K. Salzinger & S. Salzinger (Eds.) ''Research in verbal behavior and some neurophysical implications''. Academic Press, New York.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sailor |first=W. |year=1971 |title=Reinforcement and generalization of productive plural allomorphs in two retarded children |journal=Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=305–310 |pmid=16795307 |pmc=1310708 |doi=10.1901/jaba.1971.4-305}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baer | first1 = D.M. | year = 1982 | title = The imposition of structure on behavior and the demolition of behavioral structures. In H.E. Howe (Ed.) | url = | journal = Nebraska symposium on motivation | volume = 29 | issue = | pages = 217–254 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Baer |first=D.M. |last2=Guess |first2=D. |year=1973 |title=Teaching productive noun suffixes to severely retarded children |journal=American Journal of Mental Deficiency |volume=77 |issue=5 |pages=498–505 |pmid=4122226}}</ref> Multiple processes for class-like formation provide behavior analysts with relatively pragmatic explanations for common issues of novelty and generalization.
Responses are organized based upon the particular form needed to fit the current environmental challenges as well as the functional consequences. An example of large response classes lies in contingency adduction,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Andronis |first=P.T. |last2=Lang |first2=T.V.J. |last3=Goldiamond |first3=I. |year=1997 |title=Contingency adduction of "symbolic aggression" by pigeon |journal=The Analysis of Verbal Behavior |volume=16 |pages=10–23}}</ref> which is an area that needs much further research, especially with a focus on how large classes of concepts shift. For example, as [[Jean Piaget|Piaget]] observed, individuals have a tendency at the pre-operational stage to have limits in their ability to preserve information(Piaget & Szeminska, 1952). While children’s training in the development of conservation skills has been generally successful,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bucher |first=B. |last2=Schneider |first2=R.E. |year=1973 |title=Acquisition and generalization of conservation by pre-schoolers, using operant training |journal=Journal of Experimental Child Psychology |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=187–204 |doi=10.1016/0022-0965(73)90160-4}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Waghorn |first=L. |last2= Sullivan |first2=E.V. |year=1970 |title=The exploration of transition rules in conservation of quantity (substance) using film mediated modeling |journal=Acta Psychologica |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages= 65–80 |pmid=5497127 |doi=10.1016/0001-6918(70)90091-0}}</ref> complications have been noted.<ref name=Field1987>{{Cite journal |last=Field |first=D. |year=1987 |title=A review of preschool conservation training: An analysis of analyses |journal=Developmental Review |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=210–251 |doi=10.1016/0273-2297(87)90013-X}}</ref> Behavior analysts argue that this is largely due to the number of tool skills that need to be developed and integrated. Contingency adduction offers a process by which such skills can be synthesized and which shows why it deserves further attention, particularly by early childhood interventionists.
===Autism=== Ferster (1961) was the first researcher to posit a behavior analytic theory for [[autism]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ferster |first=C.B. |year=1961 |title=Positive reinforcement and the behavioral deficits of autistic children |journal=Child Development |volume=32 |pages=437–456 |pmid=13699189 |doi=10.2307/1126210}}</ref> Ferster's model saw autism as a by-product of social interactions between parent and child. Ferster presented an analysis of how a variety of contingencies of reinforcement between parent and child during early childhood might establish and strengthen a repertoire of behaviors typically seen in children diagnosed with autism. A similar model was proposed by Drash and Tutor (1993), who developed the contingency-shaped or behavioral incompatibility theory of autism.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Drash |first=P.W. |last2=Tudor |first2=R.M. |year=1993 |title=A functional analysis of verbal delay in preschool children: Implications for prevention and total recovery |journal=The Analysis of Verbal Behavior |volume=11 |pages=19–29|pmid=22477077 |pmc=2748560 }}</ref> They identified at least six [[reinforcement]] paradigms that may contribute to significant deficiencies in verbal behavior typically characteristic of children diagnosed as austistic. They proposed that each of these paradigms may also create a repertoire of avoidance responses that could contribute to the establishment of a repertoire of behavior that would be incompatible with the acquisition of age-appropriate verbal behavior. More recent models attribute [[autism]] to neurological and sensory models that are overly worked and subsequently produce the autistic repertoire. Lovaas and Smith (1989) proposed that children with autism have a mismatch between their nervous systems and the environment,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Lovaas |first=O.I. |last2=Smith |first2=T. |year=1989 |title=A comprehensive behavior theory of autistic children: Paradigm for research and treatment |journal=Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=17–29 |pmid=2671048 |doi=10.1016/0005-7916(89)90004-9}}</ref> while Bijou and Ghezzi (1999) proposed a behavioral interference theory.<ref>Bijou, S.W. & Ghezzi, P.M. (1999). The behavior interference theory of autistic behavior in young children. In P.M. Ghezzi, W.L. Williams & J.E. Carr (Eds.), ''Autism: Behavior analytic perspectives''. (pp. 33–43). Reno, NV: Context Press.</ref> However, both the environmental mismatch model and the inference model were recently reviewed,<ref>Hixson, M.D.; Wilson, J.L.; Doty, S.J. & Vladescu, J.C. (2008). A Review of the Behavioral Theories of Autism and Evidence for an Environmental Etiology. ''Journal of Speech-Language Pathology and Applied Behavior Analysis''. Special Compiled Issue 2.4 - 3.1, 46–59.</ref> and new evidence shows support for the notion that the development of autistic behaviors are due to escape and avoidance of certain types of sensory stimuli. However, most behavioral models of autism remain largely speculative due to limited research efforts.
==Role in education== One of the largest impacts of behavior analysis of child development is its role in the field of education. In 1968, Siegfried Englemann used [[operant conditioning]] techniques in a combination with rule learning to produce the [[direct instruction]] curriculum.<ref>Engelmann, S. & Carnine, D. (1991). ''Theory of instruction: Principles and applications''. Eugene, OR: ADI Press</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Englemann |first=S.E. |year=1968 |title=Relating operant techniques to programming and teaching |journal=Journal of School Psychology |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=89–96 |doi=10.1016/0022-4405(68)90002-2}}</ref> In addition, [[Fred S. Keller]] used similar techniques to develop [[programmed instruction]]. [[B.F. Skinner]] developed a programmed instruction curriculum for teaching handwriting. One of Skinner's students, [[Ogden Lindsley]], developed a standardized semilogrithmic chart, the "Standard Behavior Chart," now "Standard Celeration Chart," used to record frequencies of behavior, and to allow direct visual comparisons of both frequencies and changes in those frequencies (termed "celeration"). The use of this charting tool for analysis of instructional effects or other environmental variables through the direct measurement of learner performance has become known as [[precision teaching]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Calkin, A.B. |year=2005 |title=Precision teaching: the standard celeration charts |journal=Behav Analyst Today |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=207–16 |url= |type = PDF}}</ref>
Behavior analysts with a focus on behavioral development form the basis of a movement called [[positive behavior support]] (PBS). PBS has focused on building safe schools.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Scott |first=T.M. Gagnon |last2=Nelson |first2=C.M. |year=2008 |title=School-Wide Systems of Positive Behavior Support: A Framework for Reducing School Crime and Violence |journal=Journal of Behavior Analysis of Offender and Victim: Treatment and Prevention |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=69–80}}</ref>
In education, there are many different kinds of learning that are implemented to improve skills needed for interactions later in life. Examples of this differential learning include social and language skills.<ref>"Child Development" Northwest Regional Educational Laboratory. 2001. 5 February 2008. http://www.nwrel.org/request/june01/child.html</ref> According to the NWREL (Northwest Regional Educational Laboratory), too much interaction with technology will hinder a child's social interactions with others due to its potential to become an addiction and subsequently lead to anti-social behavior.<ref>Meltz, Barbara F. "Zora and the explorer" ''The Boston Globe'' October 22, 2007 Globe Newspaper Company 5 February 2008 http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2007/10/22/zora_and_the_explorer</ref> In terms of language development, children will start to learn and know about 5–20 different words by 18 months old.<ref>"Language Development In Children" Child Development Institute, LLC 1998–2007. 5 February 2008. http://www.childdevelopmentinfo.com/development/language_development.shtml</ref>
==Critiques of behavioral approach and new developments== Behavior analytic theories have been criticized for their focus on the explanation of the acquisition of relatively simple behavior (i.e., the behavior of nonhuman species, of infants, and of individuals who are intellectually disabled or autistic) rather than of complex behavior (see Commons & Miller).<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Commons |first=M.L. |last2=Miller |first2=P.M. |year=2001 |title=A Quantitative Behavioral Model of Developmental Stage Based upon the Model of Hierarchical Complexity |journal=The Behavior Analyst Today |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=222–252}}</ref> [[Michael Commons]] continued [[behavior analysis]]'s rejection of [[Mentalism (psychology)|mentalism]] and the substitution of a [[task analysis]] of the particular skills to be learned. In his new model, Commons has created a behavior analytic model of more complex behavior in line with more contemporary quantitative behavior analytic models called the [[model of hierarchical complexity]]. Commons constructed the model of hierarchical complexity of tasks and their corresponding stages of performance using just three main axioms.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Commons |first=M.L. |last2=Miller |first2=P.M. |year=1998 |title=A quantitative behavior-analytic theory of development |journal=Mexican Journal of Experimental Analysis of Behavior |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=153–180}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Commons |first=M.L. |last2=Trudeau |first2=E.J. |last3=Stein |first3=S.A. |last4=Richards |first4= F.A. |last5=Krause |first5=S.R. |year=1998 |title=Hierarchical Complexity of Tasks Shows the Existence of Developmental Stages |journal=Developmental Review |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=237–278 |doi=10.1006/drev.1998.0467}}</ref>
In the study of development, recent work has been generated regarding the combination of behavior analytic views with dynamical systems theory.<ref>Novak, G. & Pelaez, M. (2004). ''Child and adolescent development: A behavioral systems approach''. Sage</ref> The added benefit of this approach is its portrayal of how small patterns of changes in behavior in terms of principles and mechanisms over time can produce substantial changes in development.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Novak |first=G. |last2=Pelaez |first2=M. |year=2002 |title=A behavior-analytic developmental model is better |journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences |volume=25 |pages=466–468 |doi=10.1017/s0140525x02340081}}</ref>
Current research in behavior analysis attempts to extend the patterns learned in childhood and to determine their impact on [[adult development]].
==Professional organizations== The [[Association for Behavior Analysis]] International has a special interest group for the behavior analysis of child development.
Doctoral level behavior analysts who are psychologists belong to [[American Psychological Association]]'s division 25: [[behavior analysis]].
The World Association for Behavior Analysis has a certification in behavior therapy. The exam draws questions on behavioral theories of child development as well as behavioral theories of child psychopathology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baojournal.com/WCBA/WCBA.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110222511/http://www.baojournal.com/WCBA/WCBA.html |archivedate=2011-01-10 |df= }}</ref>

{{Italics title}} <!-- Commented out: [[File:Bestiarii (EUR Museum).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Relief of bestiarii and animals in the [[Museum of Roman Civilization]].]] --> Among [[Ancient Romans]], '''''bestiarii''''' (singular '''''bestiarius''''') were those who went into combat with beasts, or were exposed to them. It is conventional<ref name="Cyclopaedia">[http://digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/HistSciTech/HistSciTech-idx?type=turn&id=HistSciTech.Cyclopaedia01&entity=HistSciTech.Cyclopaedia01.p0247&q1=bestiarii Entry on Bestiarii] at Chambers, Ephraim, ''[[Cyclopaedia, or an Universal Dictionary of Arts and Sciences]]'', c. 1680-1740</ref> to distinguish two categories of ''bestiarii'': the first were those condemned to death via the beasts (see ''[[damnatio ad bestias]]'') and the second were those who faced them voluntarily, for pay or glory (see ''[[venatio]]'').<ref name="Smith">William Smith, [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/secondary/SMIGRA*/Bestiarii.html "Bestiarii"] from ''A Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities'', John Murray: London, 1875. Public domain.</ref> The latter are sometimes erroneously called ''[[gladiator]]s''; to their contemporaries, however, the term ''gladiator'' referred specifically to one who fought other men. The contemporary term for those who made a career out of participating in arena "hunts" was '''[[List of Roman gladiator types#Venator|venatores]]'''.
== As a form of execution == As a means of [[torture|torturous]] [[capital punishment]], death by wild beasts was a punishment for [[enemy of the state|enemies of the state]],<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/~grout/encyclopaedia_romana/gladiators/bestiarii.html The Bestiarius and the Ludus Matutinus]</ref> a category which included those taken prisoner and slaves found guilty of a serious crime. These were sent to their deaths naked and unable to defend themselves against the beasts. Even if they succeeded in killing one, fresh animals were continually let loose on them, until the ''bestiarii'' were all dead. It is reported that it was seldom necessary for two beasts to be required to take down one man. On the contrary, one beast frequently dispatched several men. [[Cicero]] mentions a single lion which alone dispatched 200 ''bestiarii''.<!--all at once, or over time?--><ref name="Cyclopaedia"/>
== Voluntary combat == ''Bestiarii'', as reported by [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]],<ref name="Cyclopaedia"/> consisted of young men who, to become expert in managing their arms, fought sometimes against beasts, and sometimes against one another; and of bravos who, to show their courage and dexterity, exposed themselves to this dangerous combat. [[Augustus]] encouraged this practice in young men of the first rank; [[Nero]] exposed himself to it; and it was for killing beasts in the [[amphitheatre]] that [[Commodus]] acquired the title of the Roman [[Hercules]].<ref name="Cyclopaedia"/>
[[Blaise de Vigenère|Vigenère]] adds two more types of ''bestiarii'':<ref>''Cyclopaedia'', apparently referring to some one of Vigenère's French translations of Latin works, such as his translation of [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]]'s ''[[Caesar's Commentaries (disambiguation)|Commentaries]]''.</ref> the first were those who made a trade of it, and fought for money. It appears that there were schools in Rome, in which people were trained to fight wild beasts (''scholae bestiarum'', or ''bestiariorum'').<ref>[[Tertullian]]'s ''[[Apologeticus]]'', [http://www.tertullian.org/latin/apologeticum_becker.htm#C35 chapter 35]; cited in Smith 1875.</ref> The second type was where several armed ''bestiarii'' were let loose at once against a number of beasts.<ref name="Cyclopaedia"/>
