The '''feminist pathways perspective''' is a feminist perspective of [[criminology]] which suggests victimization throughout the life course is a key risk factor for women's entry into offending.<ref name=":0">Davidson, Janet T. (2009). “Gender and Crime.” In ''21st Century Criminology: A Reference'' Handbook, edited by J. Miller. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications.[http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/sagetfccrim/gender_and_crime/0 (http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/sagetfccrim/gender_and_crime/0])</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Belknap|first=Joanne|date=2010|title=Offending Women: A Double Entendre|jstor=25766115|journal=The Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology|volume=100|issue=3|pages=1061–1098}}</ref><ref name=":7" /> {{Feminism sidebar}} == Victimization == {{Main|Victimisation}} Victimization has profound psychological consequences and impacts the social development of an individual.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Macmillan|first=Ross|date=2001|title=Violence and the Life Course: The Consequences of Victimization for Personal and Social Development|url=|journal=Annual Review of Sociology|volume=27|issue=1|pages=1–22|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> There is considerable evidence that victimization is a precursor to involvement in crime.<ref name=":3" /> While victimization is a risk factor for both men and women's criminal behavior, it is a stronger predictor for women.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Cauffman|first=Elizabeth|date=2008|title=Understanding the Female Offender|jstor=20179981|journal=The Future of Children|volume=18|issue=2|pages=119–142}}</ref> Although both men and women may experience victimization in their lifetime, women experience and respond to victimization differently than men due to [[Gender inequality|gender inequalities]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=The Female Offender: Girls, Women, and Crime|last=Chesney-Lind|first=Meda|publisher=Sage Publication|year=1997|isbn=|location=Thousand Oaks|pages=}}</ref> Incarcerated women experience higher rates of victimization than both incarcerated men and the general female population.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Opsal|first=Tara|last2=Foley|first2=Allison|date=2013|title=Making it on the Outside: Understanding Barriers to Women's Post-Incarceration Reintegration|journal=Sociology Compass|volume=7|issue=4|pages=265–277|doi=10.1111/soc4.12026}}</ref>
Women’s imprisonment is frequently attributed to [[Addiction|drug addiction]], [[prostitution]], and retaliation to an abuser.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=DeHart|first=Dana D.|date=2008|title=Pathways to Prison Impact of Victimization in the Lives of Incarcerated Women|url=http://vaw.sagepub.com/content/14/12/1362|journal=Violence Against Women|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1362–1381|doi=10.1177/1077801208327018|pmid=19008544}}</ref> While these attributions are characterized as crimes, research has also begun to conceptualize them as survival strategies to cope with victimization.<ref name=":10" /> A young girl, for example, may run away from an abusive home and turn to prostitution as a way to make a living. Literature on victimization has often created a division between victims and offenders.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Deadman|first=Derek|last2=MacDonald|first2=Ziggy|date=2004|title=Offenders as Victims of Crime?: An Investigation into the Relationship between Criminal Behaviour and Victimization|jstor=3559799|journal=Journal of the Royal Statistical Society|volume=167|issue=1|pages=53–67}}</ref> However, these two groups are not as separate as was once understood.<ref name=":2" />
It was not until the 1970s that research analyzed victimization, traumas, and past abuse as factors that can influence women to commit crimes. In the early 20th century, the personal histories of women in crime were not a focus of research. Early literature suggested women were antisocial due to their biology, environment, and socialization.<ref name=":1" /> [[Cesare Lombroso|Lombroso]], for instance, distinguished female offenders from non-offenders based on their physical anatomies.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Female Offender|last=Lombroso|first=Cesare|last2=Ferrero|first2=Guglielmo|last3=Morrison|first3=William Douglas|publisher=D. Appleton & Company|year=1895|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> These early explanatory factors were understood [[Individualistic culture|individualistically]] outside of a [[Social environment|social-historical context]].
=== Connection to criminal activity === There is a well-documented association between criminal behavior and victimization among female offenders.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> That said, the age and gendered patterns of victimization risk, context, and consequences are highly visible and exacerbated among incarcerated women. There is evidence to support that women involved with crime often have extensive histories of physical and sexual abuse.<ref name=":4" /> Female offenders are more likely to have been abused than male offenders<ref name=":8" /> and more likely to have been victimized than female non-offenders.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":2" /> A survey of national correctional populations found that over half of female inmates have been physically or sexually abused, compared to fewer than one in five male inmates.<ref name=":0" />
Literature suggests female offenders' victimization often begins at a young age and persists through her lifetime.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Browne|first=Angela|last2=Miller|first2=Brenda|last3=Maguin|first3=Eugene|date=1999|title=Prevalence and Severity of Lifetime Physical and Sexual Victimization Among Incarcerated Women|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160252799000114|journal=International Journal of Law and Psychiatry|volume=22|issue=3–4|pages=301–322|doi=10.1016/S0160-2527(99)00011-4}}</ref> Nearly two thirds of incarcerated women have experienced at least one event of abuse by age eleven.<ref name=":9" /> Ninety-two percent of girls under 18 in the California [[Juvenile court|juvenile justice system]] report having faced emotional, sexual, or physical abuse. Eighty percent of women in prison in the United States have experienced an event of physical or sexual abuse in her lifetime.<ref name=":8" /> This lifetime of violence is "pervasive and severe."<ref name=":9" /> The literature suggests that the prevalence of victimization among incarcerated women and its cumulative impact indicates that victimization is a central factor for women's entry into crime.<ref name=":4" />
== Demographics of victimization == The feminist pathways perspective is not meant to suggest that victimization is unique to women.<ref name=":5" /> Instead, this perspective addresses how gender impacts the experience of victimization, and how this difference in experience paves the path to crime for women. An individual's risk of victimization is shaped by environmental context, social networks, and demographics.<ref name=":3" /> [[Life course approach|Life course researchers]] maintain that people are exposed to violence to various degrees based on their location, socioeconomic circumstance, and lifestyle choices.<ref name=":3" /> According to the lifestyle exposure perspective, sociodemographic traits give rise to lifestyle differences which may put an individual at an increased risk of victimization.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Criminal Victimization in Eight American Cities|last=Hindelang|first=Michael|publisher=Ballinger|year=1976|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=}}</ref> For instance, someone from a low-income neighborhood who spends time in public places at night and among strangers may be more likely to encounter offenders, and therefore at a greater risk of victimization.
=== Age === [[File:Age of victimization chart.png|thumb|Estimated Rates (Per 1,000 Persons 12 Years of Age or Older) of Personal Victimization, By Age (Hindelang 1976)|472x472px]] Age is strongly associated with victimization risk, especially for property and violent crimes.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6" /> Victimization tends to be concentrated early in life.<ref name=":3" /> Young people are significantly more likely to experience violent victimization than older adults.<ref name=":6" /> Victimization risk peaks between ages 16 and 19.<ref name=":6" /> According to the [[National Crime Victimization Survey]], the risk of victimization increases by 8 percent from ages 12 to 15 and 16 to 19.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sourcebook of Criminal Justice Statistics- 1998|last=Bureau of Justice Statistics|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice.|year=1999|isbn=|location=Washington D.C.|pages=}}</ref> The [[Crime opportunity theory|opportunity perspective]] attributes this tendency to the way social activities are structured by age. Young adults are more likely to be in situations where they can be exposed to offenders, or engage in activities where they can be easily targeted.<ref name=":3" />
The young age at which the risk of victimization peaks has significant implications on the psychological and social development of the victim.<ref name=":3" /> Childhood is a [[critical period]] of growth, and child victims, according to the [[Cycle of violence|cycle of violence thesis]], will be more likely to be involved in violent crime in the future.<ref name=":3" /> Thus, victimization during developmental years has the potential to disrupt the normal maturation of an individual, and shape the paths this individual may take– including the pathway to prison.
=== Gender === Gender shapes the risk, context, and consequences of victimization.<ref name=":8" /> According to government statistics, with the exception of rape, men are more likely than women to be victims of all violent crimes.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=The Gender of Crime|last=Britton|first=Dana|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.|year=2011|isbn=|location=Lanham, MD|pages=82}}</ref> However, women are underrepresented as victims in official data, and are much more likely than men to be targets of certain types of victimization, such as [[rape]] and [[domestic violence]].<ref name=":8" /> Women are more likely to have been victims of [[child abuse]] than men<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Asscher|first=Jessica|last2=Put|first2=Claudia|last3=Stams|first3=Geert Jan J. M.|date=2015|title=Gender Differences in the Impact of Abuse and Neglect Victimization on Adolescent Offending Behavior|journal=Journal of Family Violence|volume=30|issue=2|pages=215–225|doi=10.1007/s10896-014-9668-4|pmid=25663744|pmc=4315896}}</ref> and more likely to have experienced abuse at an early age.<ref name=":5" />
The way victimization is gendered also impacts how women experience and respond to their victimization. Although victimization during childhood or adolescence is a predictor for female and male offending, the literature suggests it is a stronger predictor for females.<ref name=":10" /> Researchers provides multiple explanations for why victimization has such a prominent effect on women’s future delinquency. Girls grow up in what [[Meda Chesney-Lind|Chesney-Lind]] describes as a “different world”<ref name=":5" /> than boys, and therefore experience a different form of [[socialization]]. Feminist criminologists argue that women adapt to traumas differently than men due to gender inequalities.<ref name=":5" /> Women tend to have limited opportunities to cope with stress openly.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dornfeld|first=Maude|last2=Kruttschnitt|first2=Candace|date=1992|title=Do the Stereotypes Fit? Mapping Gender-Specific Outcomes and Risk Factors|url=|journal=Criminology|language=|volume=30|issue=3|pages=397–420|doi=10.1111/j.1745-9125.1992.tb01110.x|issn=}}</ref> Instead, it is thought that women internalize traumas as feelings of worthlessness, fear, or distress.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":4" /> As a result, the negative effect of stressors is magnified in women.<ref name=":10" /> The literature proposes that gendered expectations and gender roles also shape how traumas impact women differently than men.<ref name=":5" /> For instance, society teaches women that they are values by the strength of their [[Social network|familial and social networks]]. That said, poor interpersonal relationships are a stronger risk factor for female offending than male offending.<ref name=":10" /> Trauma theorists argue that traumas are rarely treated professionally.<ref name=":0" /> Women, therefore, may adapt to victimization by turning to activities or substances, like drugs, that are considered criminal.<ref name=":0" /> These crimes can be framed as coping strategies.<ref name=":10" />
=== Polyvictimization === Polyvictimization refers to experiencing different and simultaneous episodes of victimization.<ref name=":4" /> Most incarcerated women who have experienced victimization have survived multiple traumas over a lifespan.<ref name=":4" /> These repeated traumas have an aggregate impact.<ref name=":4" /> A disproportionally high number of all victimizations account for polyvictimizations.<ref name=":2" /> Women are more likely to be polyvictimized than men.<ref name=":4" /> This is likely because females are more likely to be abused than males, and find themselves in abusive relationships from childhood to adulthood.<ref name=":11" />
Research has recognized both the prevalence and mounting consequences of repeat victimization. Polyvictimization can disrupt multiple relationships and aspects of a woman’s life.<ref name=":4" /> The ripple effects of these disruptions can push a woman off the "path of normalcy."<ref name=":4" /> There is evidence that unrelenting traumas in the early stages of a young girl’s life can lead her to act criminally or "out of the mainstream"<ref name=":4" />
=== Main Routes from Victimization to Crime === Women's victimization has both direct and indirect effects that relate to women's criminal behavior.<ref name=":4" /> Among the many traumas female offenders experience in a lifetime, child abuse and partner abuse have well-documented associations with female criminal behavior.<ref name=":4" />
==== Child abuse ==== [[File:Sample Pathways From Victimization to Crime.png|thumb|Sample pathways from child abuse to crime. Inspired by DeHart (2008).|470x470px]] Female [[Juvenile delinquency|juvenile delinquents]] are more frequently victims of sexual or physical abuse than male juvenile delinquents.<ref name=":11" /> Eighty-two percent of the incarcerated women interviewed by Browne, Miller, and Maguin<ref name=":9" /> at the [[Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women|Bedford Hills Maximum Security Correctional Facility]] were abused during childhood, and nearly 60 percent had been sexually abused by a parental figure.<ref name=":9" /> Research suggests that girls experience [[child abuse]]– both physical and sexual –differently than boys.<ref name=":11" /> For instance, girls are more likely to have experienced penetrative abuse and less likely to have been physically abused.<ref name=":11" />
Childhood victimization is a strong predictor of future criminal behavior and future mental health issues.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anumba|first=Natalie|last2=Dematteo|first2=David|last3=Heilbrun|first3=Kirk|date=2012|title=Social Functioning, Victimization, and Mental Health among Female Offenders|url=http://cjb.sagepub.com/content/39/9/1204|journal=Criminal Justice and Behavior|volume=39|issue=9|pages=1204–1218|doi=10.1177/0093854812443489}}</ref> Given the gender differences in child abuse experience, the association between child abuse and delinquency is also distinct for males and females. According to data collected from the Washington State Court Juvenile Assessment data, physical child abuse is a strong predictor of women's violent behavior.<ref name=":11" /> However, there is little research on the specific mechanism that links childhood victimization and delinquent behavior.<ref name=":4" />
Feminist criminologists understand childhood victimization as a structured theme throughout the lives of incarcerated women. The long-term effects of childhood victimization are essential to understanding how women become incarcerated. For some women, childhood victimization directly relates to their involvement in crime.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite book|title=Compelled to Crime: The Gender Entrapment of Battered Black Women|last=Richie|first=Beth|publisher=Routledge|year=1996|isbn=|location=London|pages=5}}</ref> In these situations, children may be "missocialized" by caregivers who offer them drugs, force them to steal, or exploit them as prostitutes.<ref name=":4" />
[[Child abuse|Childhood victimization]] also has indirect links to future offending. There is evidence that girls from abusive households are more at risk to run away before adulthood, therefore subjecting themselves to an increased risk of becoming involved with drugs or prostitution.<ref name=":9" /> The majority of female juvenile offenders report that their first arrest was for running away from an abusive home.<ref name=":4" /> [[Prostitution]], [[property crime]]s, and [[Illegal drug trade|drug distribution]] become means of survival for young female runaways.<ref name=":4" /> Additionally, women who were physically or sexually abused as children by caretakers have a significantly higher risk of drug abuse and addiction.<ref name=":9" /> Some young women become dependent on drugs to desensitize themselves from their traumatic histories.<ref name=":4" /> Women's involvement in drugs or [[prostitution]] then significantly increases their chances of arrest or incarceration.<ref name=":0" />
==== Partner abuse ==== Studies have observed large numbers of incarcerated women who experienced [[intimate partner violence]] prior to incarceration.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /><ref name=":14" /> Seventy-five percent of the women studied by Browne, Miller, and Maguin<ref name=":9" /> at the [[Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women|Bedford Hills Maximum Security Correctional Facility]] reported histories of partner abuse. Rates of partner abuse among female offenders are higher than those among male offenders.<ref name=":15">Harlow, Caroline Wolf. (1999). ''Prior Abuse Reported by Inmates and Probationers (Report No. NCJ 172879)''. Washington, DC: Bureau of Justice Statistics, U.S. Department of Justice.</ref> A national correctional population survey from 1999 found that 61.3 percent of women had been abused by an intimate partner prior to incarceration, compared to only 5.9 percent of men.<ref name=":15" /> Research on incarcerated women suggests there is an association between childhood sexual assault and adulthood sexual assault.<ref name=":17" /> This suggests that a lifetime of victimization is characteristic of the female offender.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Raj|first=Anita|last2=Rose|first2=Jennifer|last3=Decker|first3=Michele R.|last4=Rosengard|first4=Cynthia|last5=Hebert|first5=Megan R.|last6=Stein|first6=Michael|last7=Clarke|first7=Jennifer G.|date=2008|title=Prevalence and Patterns of Sexual Assault Across the Life Span Among Incarcerated Women|url=http://vaw.sagepub.com/content/14/5/528|journal=Violence Against Women|language=en|volume=14|issue=5|pages=528–541|doi=10.1177/1077801208315528|issn=|pmid=18408171}}</ref> Partner abuse is common within this lifetime of victimization.<ref name=":9" /> Intimate partner violence has both direct and indirect implications for a woman's entry into crime.
Some feminist criminologists suggest that partner abuse coerces, if not forces, women to become involved in crime.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":14" /> In these situations, an abusive partner may entrap a woman into crime.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vawnet.org|title=Women's Experiences of Abuse as a Risk Factor for Incarceration|last=Gilfus|first=Mary|date=2002|website=|publisher=VAWnet: A Project of the National Resource Center on Domestic Violence/Pennsylvania Coalition Against Domestic Violence|access-date=}}</ref> There is evidence that incarcerated women were forced by their partners– through physical attacks or threats –to commit murders, robbery, check fraud,<ref name=":4" /> and sell or carry drugs.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":16" /> Richie observed this gender entrapment among battered African-American women in New York City jails, whom she described as being "compelled to crime."<ref name=":13" /> [[Economic abuse|Financially abusive]] partners may manipulate women into debt until they are left with no resources, and as a result, are more likely to turn to criminal activities to support themselves.<ref name=":16" />
Partner abuse also has indirect effects on the pathway to crime. There is evidence that women are sometimes implicated for crimes related to their partner abuse.<ref name=":4" /> Some women, for example, retaliated against their abuser and were imprisoned for homicide-related charges.<ref name=":4" /> Some women were implicated in the abuse of their children, who were also harmed by the abusive partner.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /> Research also finds that victims of intimate partner violence are likely to be involved with drugs.<ref name=":16" /> Drugs are either introduced by the abuser,<ref name=":16" /> or they become a self-medicated coping mechanism.<ref name=":4" /> Abusive partners sometimes isolate a woman from her social networks, thus structurally dislocating her from all legitimate institutions, such as family.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arnold|first=Regina|date=1990|title=Processes of Victimization and Criminalization of Black Women|jstor=29766565|journal=Social Justice|volume=17.3|issue=41|pages=153–166|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> Women reported feeling a sense of rejection and worthlessness as a result of this isolation, and often coped by using drugs.<ref name=":4" /> Battered women are surrounded by extreme stress and can become dependent on these substances.<ref name=":16" /> Obtaining drugs puts these women at an increased risk of arrest.<ref name=":16" />
== Critique of the victimization explanation ==
=== Women's agency ===
The feminist perspective on crime is sometimes criticized for overemphasizing or disregarding women's agency.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sexed Work: Gender, Race, and Resistance in a Brooklyn Drug Market|last=Maher|first=Lisa|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=Oxford|pages=}}</ref> Traditional feminist approaches to women in crime often overlook women's locations in society and place too much emphasis on women's individual choices.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Criminology|last=Schram|first=Pamela|last2=Tibbetts|first2=Stephen|publisher=Sage Publication|year=2014|isbn=978-1-4833-0228-7|location=Thousand Oaks|pages=307–309|chapter=Chapter 11: Feminist Theories of Crime}}</ref> This paints female offenders as active participants who are compelled to act criminally. In contrast, some research strips women of their agency and portrays them as "passive victims of oppressive social structures, relations, and substances, or some combination thereof."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Invisible Woman: Gender, Crime, and Justice|last=Belknap|first=Joanne|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2015|isbn=|location=Stamford|pages=}}</ref> This portrayal perpetuates the notion that women are always submissive to social structures.<ref name=":12" /> Critics hold that it is essential for research on women in crime to consider both the social-historical context and the woman's individual motivations.
=== Intersectionality ===
Although the feminist pathways perspective attempts to differentiate the experience of men and women in crime, it does not take into account the complex factors that also impact a woman's experiences and histories, such as race and class.<ref name=":12" /> Some critics argue that a "feminist" perspective too often only considers the experiences of a white, middle-class woman.<ref name=":12" /> Just as gender acts as an organizing principle in society, race and class also shape opportunity structures and social positions.<ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Gender Through the Prism of Difference|last=Zinn|first=Maxine Baca|last2=Hondagneu-Sotelo|first2=Pierrette|last3=Denissen|first3=Amy|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> A suburban upper-class, white woman, for instance, will likely encounter different forms of victimization in her lifetime than a lower-income, African American woman who lives in a crime-ridden neighborhood. An [[Intersectionality|intersectional]], or interlocking, perspective takes into account that other social identities impact an individual's victimization and path into crime. [[White feminism|Multicultural feminism]] is necessary to fully understand how social identities interact with traumatic life course events to pave the way to prison.
=== Separating offenders and victims ===
Feminist scholars have strongly discouraged researchers from portraying female offenders and victims as mutually exclusive groups.<ref name=":12" /> Instead, critics argue the line between them should be blurred because women's involvement in crime is so often linked to their subordinate social positions, which make them vulnerable to victimization.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Gilfus|first=Mary|date=1993|title=From Victims to Survivors to Offenders|journal=Women & Criminal Justice|volume=4|issue=1|pages=63–89|doi=10.1300/J012v04n01_04|issn=}}</ref><ref name=":12" /> Critics hold that women can only be understood as criminals if they are also understood as victims, necessitating fluidity between offenders and victims.<ref name=":12" />

revision.comment: /* Static spacetime */
revision.text:
In [[general relativity]] the light is assumed to propagate in the [[vacuum]] along [[null geodesic]] in a [[pseudo-Riemannian manifold]]. Besides the geodesics principle in a [[classical field theory]] there exists the [[Fermat's principle]] for [[stationary spacetime|stationary gravity fields]].<ref name = "Land">{{Citation|author=Landau, Lev D.|authorlink=Lev Landau|author2= Lifshitz, Evgeny F.| author2-link=Evgeny Lifshitz|title=The Classical Theory of Fields (4th ed.)|location=London|publisher=[[Butterworth-Heinemann]]|date=1980|isbn=9780750627689| page = 273}}</ref>
== Fermat's principle ==
In more general case for [[Conformal manifold|conformally]] [[stationary spacetime]] <ref name = "Perl">{{Citation|author= Perlik, Volker |title=Gravitational Lensing from a Spacetime Perspective|journal= Living Rev. Relativ.| volume=7| date=2004| issue=9|at=Chapter 4.2}}</ref> with [[coordinates]] <math>(t,x^1,x^2,x^3) </math> a Fermat [[Metric tensor|metric]] takes form
:<math>g=e^{2f(t,x)}[(dt+\phi_{\alpha}(x)dx^{\alpha})^{2}-\hat{g}_{\alpha\beta} dx^{\alpha} dx^{\beta}]</math>,
where conformal factor <math>f(t,x)</math> depending on time <math>t</math> and [[space]] coordinates <math>x^{\alpha}</math> does not affect the [[lightlike]] geodesics apart from their parametrization.
Fermat's principle for a pseudo-Riemannian manifold states that the light ray path between points <math>x_a=(x^1_a,x^2_a,x^3_a) </math> and <math>x_b=(x^1_b,x^2_b,x^3_b) </math> corresponds to zero variation of [[Action (physics)|action]]
:<math>S=\int^{\mu_a}_{\mu_b}\left(\sqrt{\hat{g}_{\alpha\beta} \frac{dx^{\alpha}}{d\mu} \frac{dx^{\beta}}{d\mu}}+\phi_{\alpha}(x)\frac{dx^{\alpha}}{d\mu} \right) d\mu</math>,
where <math>\mu</math> is any parameter ranging over an [[Interval (mathematics)|interval]] <math>[\mu_a, \mu_b] </math> and varying along [[curve]] with fixed endpoints <math>x_a=x(\mu_a) </math> and <math>x_b=x(\mu_b)</math>.
==Principle of stationary integral of energy ==
In principle of stationary integral of energy for a light-like particle's motion, the pseudo-Riemannian metric with coefficients <math>\tilde{g}_{ij}</math> is defined by a transformation
:<math> \tilde{g}_{00} =\rho ^{2}{g}_{00} ,\,\,\,\, \tilde{g}_{0k}=\rho{g}_{0k} ,\,\,\,\, \tilde{g}_{kq} ={g}_{kq} .</math>
With time coordinate <math>x^0</math> and space coordinates with indexes ''k,q=1,2,3'' the [[line element]] is written in form
:<math> ds^2=\rho^2 g_{00}(dx^{0})^{2}+ 2\rho g_{0k}dx^{0}dx^{k}+g_{kq}dx^{k}dx^{q},</math>
where <math>\rho </math> is some quantity, which is assumed equal 1 and regarded as the energy of the light-like particle with <math>ds=0</math>. Solving this equation for <math>\rho </math> under condition <math>g_{00} \ne 0</math> gives two solutions
:<math>\rho =\frac{-g_{0k} v^{k} \pm \sqrt{(g_{0k} g_{0q} -g_{00} g_{kq})v^{k} v^{q} } }{g_{00} v^{0} },</math>
where <math>v^{i}=dx^i/d\mu</math> are elements of the [[four-velocity]]. Even if one solution, in accordance with making definitions, is <math>\rho=1 </math>.
With <math>g_{00}=0</math> and <math>g_{0k} \ne 0</math> even if for one ''k'' the energy takes form
:<math>\rho =-\frac{g_{kq} v^{k} v^{q} }{2v_{0} v^{0}}.</math>
In both cases for the [[Free motion equation|free moving]] particle the [[Lagrangian mechanics|Lagrangian]] is
:<math>L= -\rho.</math>
Its [[partial derivatives]] give the [[Momentum|canonical momenta]]
:<math>p_{\lambda}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial v^{\lambda}}=\frac{v_{\lambda}}{v^{0}v_{0}}</math>
and the [[forces]]
: <math>F_{\lambda}=\frac{\partial L }{\partial x^{\lambda}}=\frac{1}{2v^{0}v_{0}}\frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^{\lambda}}v^{i}v^{j}.</math>
Momenta satisfy energy condition <ref name = "Land2">{{Citation|author=Landau, Lev D.|authorlink=Lev Landau|author2= Lifshitz, Evgeny F.| author2-link=Evgeny Lifshitz|title= Mechanics Vol. 1 (3rd ed.)|location=London|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|date=1976|isbn=9780750628969| page = 14}}</ref> for [[closed system]]
:<math>\rho=v^{\lambda}p_{\lambda}-L,</math>
and thus <math>\rho</math> is [[Hamiltonian mechanics|Hamiltonian]].
Standard [[variational method|variational procedure]] according to [[Hamilton's principle]] is applied to action
:<math> S=\int^{\mu_a}_{\mu_b}L d\mu=-\int^{\mu_a}_{\mu_b}\rho d\mu, </math>
which is integral of energy. Stationary action is conditional upon zero variational derivatives {{math|''δS''/''δx''<sup>λ</sup> }} and leads to [[Euler–Lagrange equations]]
:<math>\frac{d}{d\mu}\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial v^{\lambda}}-\frac{\partial \rho }{\partial x^{\lambda}}=0,</math>
which is rewritten in form
:<math>\frac{d}{d\mu} p_{\lambda}-F_{\lambda}=0.</math>
After substitution of canonical momentum and forces they give motion equations of lightlike particle in a [[free space]]
:<math>\frac{dv^{0}}{d\mu}+\frac{v^{0}}{2v_{0}}\frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^{0}}v^{i}v^{j}=0</math>
and
:<math> (g_{k\lambda} v_{0}-g_{0k}v_{\lambda})\frac{dv^{k}}{d\mu}+\left[\frac{1}{2v_{0}}\frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^{0}}(g_{00}v^{0}v_{\lambda}+ g_{k\lambda}v^{k}v_{0})-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\partial g_{ij}}{\partial x^{\lambda}}v_{0} +\frac{\partial g_{i\lambda}}{\partial x^{j}}v_0- \frac{\partial g_{0i}}{\partial x^{j}}v_{\lambda}\right]v^i v^j=0.</math>
== Static spacetime == For the [[Isotropic_line|isotropic paths]] a transformation to metric <math> \overline{g}_{ij}=g_{ij}/{g_{00}}</math> is equivalent to replacement of parameter <math>\mu</math> on <math>d\overline{\mu}=d\mu/\sqrt{g_{00}}</math> to which the four-velocities <math>\overline{v}^{i}=dx^i/d\overline{\mu}</math> correspond. The curve of motion of lightlike particle in [[four-dimensional space]]time and value of energy <math>\rho </math> are [[invariant (physics)|invariant]] under this reparametrization. For the [[static spacetime]] the first equation of motion with appropriate parameter <math>\overline \mu</math> gives <math>\overline v^0=1</math> . Canonical momentum and forces take form
:<math>\overline{p}_{\lambda}=\overline v_{\lambda}; \qquad \overline{F}_{\lambda}=\frac{1}{2}\frac{\partial \overline{g}_{ij}}{\partial x^{\lambda}}\overline{v}^{i}\overline{v}^{j}.</math>
Substitution of them in Euler–Lagrange equations gives
:<math>\frac{d}{d\mu}\left(\overline{g}_{\lambda k} \overline{v}^k\right)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{\partial \overline{g}_{ij}}{\partial x^{\lambda}}\overline{v}^{i}\overline{v}^{j}</math>.
After differentiation on the left side and multiplying by <math>\overline{g}^{l \lambda}</math> this expression, after the summation over the repeated index <math>\lambda</math>, becomes null geodesic equations
:<math>\frac{d^2 x^l}{d\overline{\mu}^2}+\Gamma^l_{ij} \frac{dx^i}{d\overline{\mu}}\frac{dx^j}{d\overline{\mu}}=0,</math>
where <math>\Gamma^l_{ij}</math> are the second kind [[Christoffel symbols]] with respect to the [[metric tensor]] <math> \overline{g}_{ij}</math>.
So in case of the static spacetime the geodesic principle and the energy variational method as well as Fermat's principle give the same solution for the light propagation.

{{RCL}} '''General Chinese''' ({{zh|通字}} ''Tung-dzih'') is a [[diaphonemic]] orthography invented by [[Chao Yuen Ren|Yuen Ren Chao]] to represent the pronunciations of all major varieties of Chinese simultaneously.Chao (1983). It is "the most complete genuine Chinese diasystem yet published".Branner 2006:231. More recent diaphonemic systems, such as Ao (1991) and Norman (2006), cover a smaller number of morphemes. Norman also excludes Min, though he covers a larger number of non-Min dialects than Chao. It can also be used for the [[Hanja|Korean]], [[on'yomi|Japanese]], and [[Sino-Vietnamese vocabulary|Vietnamese]] [[Sinoxenic|pronunciations of Chinese characters]], and challenges the claim that [[Chinese character]]s are required for interdialectal communication in written Chinese. General Chinese is not specifically a romanization system, but two alternative systems: one (''Tung-dzih Xonn-dzih'') uses Chinese characters phonetically, as a [[syllabary]] of 2082 glyphs, and the other (''Tung-dzih Lo-maa-dzih'') is an alphabetic romanization system with similar sound values and tone spellings to [[Gwoyeu Romatzyh]]. ==Character-based General Chinese== The character version of General Chinese uses distinct characters for any traditional characters that are distinguished [[phoneme|phonemically]] in any of the control varieties of Chinese, which consist of several dialects of [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Wu Chinese|Wu]], [[Min Chinese|Min]], [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]], and [[Cantonese language|Yue]]. That is, a single syllabic character will only correspond to more than one logographic character when these are [[homonym]]s in all control dialects. In effect, General Chinese is a syllabic reconstruction of the pronunciation of [[Middle Chinese]], less distinctions which have been dropped nearly everywhere. The result is a syllabary of 2082 syllables, about 80% of which are single morphemes—that is, in 80% of cases there is no difference between GC and standard written Chinese, and in running text, that figure rises to 90–95%, as the most common morphemes tend to be uniquely identified. For example, ''kai'' can only mean 開 ''kāi'' 'open', and ''sam'' can only mean 三 ''sān'' 'three'.Excepting rare, obsolete, or variant characters, such as 叁, the bank variant of ''sān'' 'three'. Chao notes, "These syllables then are morphemes, or words with definite meanings, or clusters of meanings related by extensions. About 20 percent of the syllables are homophones under each of which there will be more than one morpheme, [which are traditionally] usually written with different characters [...] The degree of homophony is so low that it will be possible to write text either in literary or colloquial Chinese with the same character for each syllable [...] as has been tested in texts of various styles." Chao compares General Chinese to how Chinese was written when the writing system was still productive: "This amounts to a 100 percent use of writing Chinese by '[[Phonetic loan character|phonetic loan]]' [...] The situation is that when the ancients wrote a character by sound regardless of meaning, it was a 'loan character', whereas if a modern schoolboy writes one, he is punished for writing the wrong character!"Chao 1976:107–108. Taking a telegraphic code-book of about 10,000 characters as a representative list of characters in modern use,Since, as he put it, "most of the additional [characters in a large dictionary] are simply graphical variants or quite obsolete words" (Chao 1976:115). Chao notes that General Chinese results in a reduction of 80% in the number of characters needing to be learned. In the 20% of cases where a syllable corresponded to more than one word, Chao generally selected the graphically most basic traditional character for General Chinese, as long as it wasn't unduly rare. However, when that character had strong semantic connotations that would have interfered with a phonetic reading, he selected a more neutral character. This phenomenon is familiar from [[Transcription into Chinese characters|Chinese transcriptions of foreign names]]. ==Romanized General Chinese== Romanized General Chinese has distinct symbols for the [[Rime table#Initials|onsets]] (many of them [[Digraph (orthography)|digraphs]], and a few trigraphs) and the [[Rime table#Finals|rimes]] distinguished by any of the control dialects. For example, it retains the final consonants ''p, t, k'', and the distinction between final ''m'' and ''n'', as these are found in several modern dialects, such as Cantonese. General Chinese also maintains the "round-sharp" distinction, such as ''sia'' vs. ''hia'', though those are both ''xia'' in Beijing Mandarin. It also indicates the "muddy" (voiced) [[stop consonant|stops]] of [[Shanghainese]]. Indeed, Chao characterized GC as having "the initial consonants of the Wu dialects [...], the vowels of Mandarin, and the endings of Cantonese. It can, however, be pronounced in any dialect, and it is meant to be, by a relatively short list of rules of pronunciation."Chao 1976:106. Like Chao's other invention, Gwoyeu Romatzyh, romanized General Chinese uses tone spelling. However, the system is somewhat different. The difference between the [[four tones|''yin'' and ''yang'' tones]] is indicated by the [[Voice (phonetics)|voicing]] of the initial [[consonant]], which is possible because the original voicing distinctions are retained. Given that some tones are indicated by changing rather than adding letters, writing tone requires on average only one additional letter for every three syllables of text. The digraphs are not reliably [[distinctive feature|featural]]; for example, the digraphs for the voiced stops do not all follow the same pattern. This is because Chao ran frequency tests, and used single letters for the most common consonants and [[vowels]], while restricting digraphs and [[Digraphs and trigraphs|trigraphs]] to the more infrequent ones. Overall, syllables in the texts he transliterated averaged under 3½ letters apiece. An example of Romanized General Chinese can be illustrated with Chao's name: {|class="wikitable" !Traditional
characters ! 趙 ! 元 ! 任 ! Notes |- ! General Chinese | dhyao | qiuan | remm | |- ! rowspan="2" | Mandarin ([[Modern Standard Chinese|MSC]]) | jaw | yuan | renn | ([[Gwoyeu Romatzyh|GR]]) |- | zhào | yuán | rèn | ([[Pinyin]]) |- ! rowspan="2" | Yuè ([[Cantonese]]) | jiuh | yùhn | yahm | ([[Yale romanization of Cantonese|Yale]]) |- | ziu6 | jyun4 | jam6 | ([[Jyutping]]) |- ! Mǐnnán ([[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese]]) | tiō | gôan | jīm | ([[Pe̍h-ōe-jī|POJ]]) |- ! Wú ([[Shanghainese]]) | dzau | gnioe | gnin | |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Japanese language|Japanese]], ''[[go-on|go'on]]'' reading | deu | gwan | nin | (Pre-WWII) |- | jō | gan | nin | (Post-WWII) |- ! rowspan="2" | Japanese, ''[[kan-on|kan'on]]'' reading | teu | gen | zin | (Pre-WWII) |- | chō | gen | jin | (Post-WWII) |- ! rowspan="2" | [[Korean language|Korean]] | cho | wŏn | im | ([[McCune-Reischauer]]) |- | jo | won | yim | ([[Revised Romanization of Korean|Revised Romanization]]) |- ! [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] | triệu | nguyên | nhẩm | ([[Vietnamese alphabet|Chữ quốc ngữ]]) |- |} All the General Chinese initials here are voiced: The ''h'' in ''dh'' shows that this is a "muddy" consonant, and the ''q'' in ''qiuan'' represents an initial ''ng-'' (becoming ''g'' in Japanese). This voicing shows up in the Cantonese ''yang'' tones, which are represented by aitches in Yale romanization. "Heavy" codas, such as ''remm'', indicate the "departing" (去) tone, as in Gwoyeu Romatzyh. Similarly, the spelling ''ao'' in ''dhyao'' indicates the "rising" (上) tone, but because of the voiced initial, it merges with "departing" in Mandarin and literary Cantonese (though not in colloquial Cantonese). The ''y'' in ''dhyao'' indicates that the initial is a stop in Min, Japanese, and Vietnamese, but otherwise an affricate. Cantonese and Korean retain the final ''m'' of ''remm''. These pronunciations are all predictable given the General Chinese transcription, though it was not designed with the Sinospheric languages specifically in mind. Both the pre-war and post-war Japanese orthographies are recoverable. In every control dialect, some syllables with different spellings will be pronounced the same. However, which these are differs from dialect to dialect. There are some irregular correlations: Often a particular variety will have a pronunciation for a syllable that is not what one would expect from other syllables with similar spellings, due to irregular developments in that variety. This is especially true with the voicing of Japanese consonants, which has evolved idiosyncratically in different compound words. However, except for Japanese voicing, the system is phonetic about 90% of the time. ===Utility of romanized General Chinese vs. traditional characters=== A common argument for retaining Chinese characters is that romanization systems are insufficient to unambiguously represent the Chinese language, due to the large number of homonyms. (However, the Chinese military has found pinyin to be sufficient to telegraph military communications, even without indicating tone.){{citation needed|date=February 2013}} Because General Chinese makes many distinctions that Pinyin does not, it has many fewer homonyms to confuse the reader. Combine this with the fact that many traditional Chinese characters are restricted to specific compounds, and that many homonymic characters distinguish meanings of what are historically the same word, and which are therefore understandable in context, Chao believed that General Chinese begins to approach the effectiveness of traditional characters in representing Chinese. ==Onsets and rhymes== Character GC has a separate character for each syllable. However, romanized GC has distinct onsets and rhymes. The onsets are as follows: ===Onsets=== {| class="wikitable" |+The 36 initials ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! colspan="3" | stops and affricates ! colspan="2" | fricatives ! rowspan="2" | sonorants |- !tenuis!!aspirate!!voiced!!tenuis!!voiced |- ! colspan="2" | bilabial | {{angbr|'''b'''}} {{tooltip|幫|bāng}} {{IPA|/p/}} | {{angbr|'''p'''}} {{tooltip|滂|pāng}} {{IPA|/pʰ/}} | {{angbr|'''bh'''}} {{tooltip|並|bìng}} {{IPA|/b/}} | | | {{angbr|'''m'''}} {{tooltip|明|míng}} {{IPA|/m/}} |- ! colspan="2" | labiodental | | | | {{angbr|'''f'''}} {{tooltip|非|fēi}}{{tooltip|敷|fū}} {{IPA|/f/}} | {{angbr|'''fv'''}} {{tooltip|奉|fèng}} {{IPA|/v/}} | {{angbr|'''v'''}} {{tooltip|微|wēi}} {{IPA|/w̃/}}An unusual initial; shows up today as either {{IPA|/w/}} or {{IPA|/m/}}. |- ! rowspan="2" | dental ! stops | {{angbr|'''d'''}} {{tooltip|端|duān}} {{IPA|/t/}} | {{angbr|'''t'''}} {{tooltip|透|tòu}} {{IPA|/tʰ/}} | {{angbr|'''dh'''}} {{tooltip|定|dìng}} {{IPA|/d/}} | | | rowspan="2" | {{angbr|'''n'''}} {{tooltip|泥|ní}}{{tooltip|娘|niáng}} {{IPA|/n/}},
{{angbr|'''l'''}} {{tooltip|來|lái}} {{IPA|/l/}} |- ! sibilants | {{angbr|'''z'''}} {{tooltip|精|jīng}} {{IPA|/ts/}} | {{angbr|'''ts'''}} {{tooltip|清|qīng}} {{IPA|/tsʰ/}} | {{angbr|'''dz'''}} {{tooltip|從|cóng}} {{IPA|/dz/}} | {{angbr|'''s'''}} {{tooltip|心|xīn}} {{IPA|/s/}} | {{angbr|'''sz'''}} {{tooltip|邪|xié}} {{IPA|/z/}} |- ! colspan="2" | laryngeal | ∅ {{tooltip|影|yǐng}} {{IPA|/ʔ/}} | colspan="4" | | {{angbr|'''y, w, h'''}} {{tooltip|喻|yù}} {{IPA|/j/}} |} 泥 and 娘 are both transcribed {{angbr|n}}, as these are not distinct in modern dialects. 喻, a conflation of two older initials, 云 ''hy~hw'' and 以 ''y~w'', is transcribed {{angbr|h}} or ∅ according to modern rather than ancient forms; when palatalization is lost, it is transcribed {{angbr|w}}. The palatal and retroflex fricatives 照穿牀審禪 fell together early on in the rime tables of Classical Chinese, but are still distinguished in some modern dialects, and so are distinguished here. The convention {{angbr|q}} for nasal 疑, which drops in many dialects, is repeated in the finals, where it represents {{IPA|*[ŋ]}} with a departing tone. Although to some extent systematic—the retroflex series are digraphs ending in {{angbr|r}}, for example—this is overridden in many cases by the principle of using short transcriptions for common sounds. Thus {{angbr|z}} is used for 精 rather than for the less common 邪, where it might also be expected; {{angbr|v}} is used for frequent 微 rather than for 奉; and {{angbr|c}} and {{angbr|g}}, for the high-frequency 見 and 羣, have the additional benefit of being familiar in their palatalized forms (Peking ~ Beijing for example is -{{angbr|cieng}}) from English words like ''cello'' and ''gem.'' ====Dialectal correspondences==== The voiced obstruents (the 濁 "muddy" column) are only distinct in Wu dialects. In Min, they are collapsed with the consonants of the tenuis column. Elsewhere they are generally collapsed with the aspirated column in the even tone, and with the tenuis column in other tones. An exception is Cantonese, where in the rising tone they are aspirated in colloquial speech, but tenuis in reading pronunciations. The sonorants do not vary much apart from {{angbr|v}}, {{angbr|r}}, which in Wu are nasals {{IPA|[m], [ɲ]}} colloquially but fricatives {{IPA|[v], [z]}} when read. Velars {{angbr|c}}, {{angbr|k}}, {{angbr|g}} are palatalized to affricates before {{angbr|i}}, {{angbr|iu}} (the high-front vowels {{IPA|[i], [y]}}) apart from Min and Yue, where they remain stops before all vowels; {{angbr|x}}, {{angbr|h}} also palatalize, but remain fricatives. For instance in Mandarin, they are ''g, k, h'' before non-palatalizing vowels and ''j, q, x'' before palatalizing vowels, whereas in Cantonese they remain ''g, k, h'' everywhere. (Compare the alternate spellings of ''Beijing'' and ''Peking''.) The alveolar sibilants {{angbr|z}}, {{angbr|ts}}, {{angbr|dz}}, {{angbr|s}}, {{angbr|sz}} (Mandarin ''z, c, s'') are also generally palatalized before {{angbr|i}}, {{angbr|iu}} (to Mandarin ''j, q, x''), collapsing with the palatalized velars {{angbr|c}}, {{angbr|k}}, {{angbr|g}}, {{angbr|x}}, {{angbr|h}} in dialects which have lost the "round-sharp" distinction so important to Peking opera. The palatal stops {{angbr|dy}}, {{angbr|ty}}, {{angbr|dhy}} remain stops only in Min among the Chinese lects (though also in Japanese and Vietnamese loan words); elsewhere they are conflated with the affricates. The palatal and retroflex sibilants are generally conflated; in Yue and Min, as well as in much of Wu and Mandarin, they are further conflated with the alveolar sibilants. This contrast remains in Beijing, where {{IPA|[sán]}} 'three' is distinct from {{IPA|[ʂán]}} 'mountain'; both are {{IPA|[sán]}} in Sichuanese and Taiwanese Mandarin. There are numerous more sporadic correlations. For instance, the alveolar affricates {{angbr|z}}, {{angbr|ts}}, {{angbr|dz}} become stops {{IPA|[t], [tʰ]}} in Taishan Yue, whereas the alveolar stops are [[debuccalization|debuccalized]] to {{IPA|[ʔ], [h]}}, as in ''Hoisaan'' for Cantonese ''Toisaan'' (Taishan). In [[Yüchi, Yunnan]], it is the velars {{angbr|c}}, {{angbr|k}}, {{angbr|g}} which are debuccalized, to {{IPA|[ʔ], [ʔʰ]}}. In the Min dialects, {{angbr|f}}, {{angbr|fv}} become {{IPA|[h]}} or {{IPA|[ʍ]}}. In Xi'an Mandarin, the fricatives {{angbr|sh}}, {{angbr|sr}}, {{angbr|zh}}, {{angbr|zr}} are rounded to {{IPA|[f]}} before [[rounded vowel]]s, as in {{IPA|[fêi]}} 'water' (Beijing ''shuǐ'' {{IPA|[ʂwèi]}}). ===Medials=== The categories of the Late Middle Chinese [[rime table]]s are reduced to the four medials of modern Chinese, plus an intermediate type {{angbr|e}}: {| class=wikitable ! rowspan="2" | ! rowspan="2" | Division I!!colspan="2" | Division II!!rowspan="2" | Divisions III and IV |- ! others!! back initials |- align="center" ! Closed (合) | colspan="3" | {{tooltip|合|hé}} {{angbr|'''u'''}} || {{tooltip|撮|cuō}} {{angbr|'''iu'''}} |} ⟨i⟩ and ⟨iu⟩ are omitted after labiodental initials. ====Dialectal correspondences==== The medial {{angbr|e}} is used for syllables which have a palatalizing medial {{IPA|[i]}} in Mandarin, but no medial in Yue. That is, in Mandarin {{angbr|e}} should be read as {{angbr|i}}, with the same effect on consonants as {{angbr|i}} has, whereas in Cantonese it is silent. In Shanghainese both situations occur: {{angbr|e}} is equivalent to {{angbr|i}} in reading pronunciations, as {{IPA|[i]}} or {{IPA|[y]}}, but is not found in colloquial speech. In Cantonese, medial {{angbr|i}} can be ignored after sibilants, as palatalization has been lost in these series. That is, ''siao, shao'' are read the same. ===Rimes=== Chao uses the following rimes. They do not always correspond to the [[Middle Chinese#Finals|Middle Chinese rimes]]. Rimes consist of a nucleus (the main vowel) and optionally a coda. They need to be considered as a unit because of a strong historical interaction between vowel and coda in Chinese dialects. leus !!o | || ||om||on||ong |- !rowspan=2|a |rowspan=2|ai||rowspan=2|au||rowspan=2|am||rowspan=2|an||rowspan=1|ang |- |rowspan=2|aeng |- !rowspan=2|e |rowspan=2|ei||rowspan=2|eu||rowspan=2|em||rowspan=2|en |- |eng |- !i | || ||im||in||ing |- !u | || || ||un||ung |} ====Dialectal correspondences==== The most salient dialectal difference in rimes is perhaps the lack of the obstruent codas {{angbr|p}}, {{angbr|t}}, {{angbr|c}} in most dialects of Mandarin and independently in the [[Wencheng dialect]] of [[Oujiang Chinese|Oujiang]], though this has traditionally been seen as a loss of ''tone'' (see below). In Wu, Min (generally), New Xiang (Hunanese), Jin, and in the [[Lower Yangtze Mandarin|Lower Yangtze]] and [[Minjiang dialect|Minjiang]] dialects of Mandarin, these codas conflate to [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/ʔ/}}. In others, such as Gan, they are reduced to {{IPA|[t], [k]}}, while Yue dialects, Hakka, and Old Xiang maintain the original {{IPA|[p], [t], [k]}} system. Nasal codas are also reduced in many dialects. Mandarin and Wu do not distinguish between {{angbr|m}} and {{angbr|n}}, with them being reduced to {{IPA|[n]}} or nasal vowels, or in some cases dropped altogether. In Shanghainese many instances of {{angbr|nɡ}} have conflated as well, or been dropped, but a phonemic distinction is maintained. In Mandarin, an additional coda is found, ''-er'' {{IPA|[ɻ]}}, from GC {{angbr|ri}}.The "[[erhua]]" reported from northern Wu dialects such as [[Hangzhou dialect|Hangzhou]] actually involves suffixing a nasal {{IPA|[ŋ]}}, not {{IPA|[ɻ]}}. In Cantonese, the simple vowels ''i u iu o a e'' are {{IPA|[iː uː yː ɔː aː ɛː]}}, apart from {{angbr|i}} and {{angbr|iu}} after velars, which open to diphthongs, as in ''ci'' {{IPA|[kei]}} and ''ciu'' {{IPA|[kɵy]}}. Diphthongs may vary markedly depending on initial and medial, as in ''cau'' {{IPA|[kou]}}, ''ceau'' {{IPA|[kaːu]}}, ''ciau'' {{IPA|[kiːu]}}, though both ''ceu ~ cieu'' are {{IPA|[kɐu]}}, following the general pattern of {{angbr|e}} before a coda (cf. ''cen'' {{IPA|[kɐn]}} vs ''can'' {{IPA|[kaːn]}}). Cantonese does not have medials, apart from ''gw, kw'', though sometimes it is the nuclear vowel which drops: ''giung'' {{IPA|[kʰoŋ]}}, ''xiong'' {{IPA|[hoŋ]}}, but ''giuan'' {{IPA|[kʰyːn]}}. === Combinations of medials and rimes === The following combinations of orthographic medials and rimes occur, taking ''-iu'' to be medial ''i'' + rime ''u'' : {| class=wikitable ! !!o!!a!!e!!ai!!ei!!i!!u!!au!!eu!!om!!am!!em!!im!!on!!an!!en!!un!!in!!ang*!!aeng!!eng!!ing!!ung!!ong* |-align=center !e | ||ea|| ||eai|| || || ||eau|| || ||eam|| || || ||ean|| || || || eang||eaeng‡|| || || || |-align=center !i | ||ia||ie|| || || ||iu||iau||ieu|| ||colspan=2|iem|| || ||colspan=2|ien||iun|| || iang||colspan=2|ieng|| ||iung||iong |-align=center !u |uo||ua|| ||uai||uei||ui|| || || || || || || ||uon||uan|| || || || uang||uaeng||ueng|| || || |-align=center !iu | || ||iue|| || || || || || || || || || || ||colspan=2|iuan§|| || || ||colspan=2|iueng||iuing|| || |} :* In entering tone, ''ang (eang, iang, uang)'' changes to ''oc (eoc, ioc, uoc)'', and ''ong (iong)'' changes to ''ouc (iouc)'' :‡ ''-eaeng'' is generally shortened to ''-aeng'' :§ In entering tone, ''iuan'' changes to ''iuet'' Double cells show discrepancies between analysis and orthography. Min dialects are similar, but in certain tones {{angbr|i}} and {{angbr|iu}} become diphthongs rather that their usual {{IPA|[i], [y]}}. For example, in Fuzhou, even-tone 星 ''sieng'' is {{IPA|[siŋ]}} but going-tone 性 ''sieq'' is {{IPA|[seiŋ]}}. In Yunnan Mandarin, {{angbr|iu}} is pronounced as {{angbr|i}}, so that the name of the province, ''yunnom'', is {{IPA|[inna]}} rather than {{IPA|[ynnan]}} as in Beijing. In Nanking, {{angbr|ien}} [[metathesis (linguistics)|metathesizes]] to {{IPA|[ein]}} after alveolars, as in 天 {{IPA|[tʰein]}} for Beijing ''tian'' {{IPA|[tʰiɛn]}}. ===Tones=== The basic spelling is used for the even 平 tone(s). For the rising 上 tone(s), the nucleus is doubled (with the vowel {{angbr|iu}} → {{angbr|iuu}}, as that is treated as medial {{angbr|i}} + nucleus {{angbr|u}}), or the coda is changed to a 'lighter' letter. For the going 去 tone(s), the coda is made 'heavier'; if there is no coda, add {{angbr|h}}. For the entering 入 tone(s), a stop coda is used. 'Lighter' means that a vowel coda is made more [[relative articulation#Lowered|open]] ({{angbr|i}} → {{angbr|e}}, {{angbr|u}} → {{angbr|o}}); 'heavier' means that a vowel coda is made more [[relative articulation#Raised|close]] ({{angbr|i}} → {{angbr|y}}, {{angbr|u}} → {{angbr|w}}) and a nasal coda ({{angbr|n}}, {{angbr|m}}) is doubled. The nasal {{angbr|ng}} is 'lightened' to {{angbr|g}} (as in many Polynesian languages) and made heavier as {{angbr|q}} (as in the GC initial): {| class=wikitable |- ! coda !! even 平 !! rising 上 !! going 去 !! entering 入 |- ! rowspan=2|(none) |ba || baa || bah || — |- |ciu || ciuu || ciuh || — |- ! -i | fui || fue || fuy || — |- ! -u | cau || cao || caw || — |- ! -m | lam || laam || lamm || lap |- ! -n | ren || reen || renn || ret |- ! -ng | jang || jag || jaq || joc |} One consequence of this is that the rimes ''-e'' and ''-ei'' in the even tone conflate to {{angbr|ee}} in the rising tone. However, since there are no such syllables which begin with the same consonant and medial, no syllables are actually conflated. The difference between ''yin'' and ''yang'' tones is indicated by the voicing of the consonant. A zero consonant is treated as voiceless (it is sometimes reconstructed as a [[glottal stop]]), so ''i, iem, uon, iuan'' are ''ping yin'' (Mandarin ''yī, yān, wān, yuān''), whereas ''yi, yem, won, yuan'' are ''ping yang'' (Mandarin ''yí, yán, wán, yuán''). In a few cases, the effect that voiced {{angbr|m}}, {{angbr|n}}, {{angbr|l}}, {{angbr|r}} have on tone needs to be negated to achieve a ''ping yin'' tone. This is accomplished by spelling them {{angbr|mh}}, {{angbr|nh}}, {{angbr|lh}}, {{angbr|rh}}. To mark the toneless Mandarin syllable ''ma'', a centered dot is used: {{angbr|·ma}}. The dot is omitted for toneless {{angbr|me, de, te, ne, le}}, as tonic ''me, de, te, ne, le'' do not exist. ====Dialectal correspondences==== The realization of the tones in the various varieties of Chinese is generally predictable; see [[Four tones]] for details. In Beijing Mandarin, for example, even tone is split according to voicing, with muddy consonants becoming aspirates: ''ba, pa, ma, bha'' → ''bā, pā, má, pá'' (and ''mha'' → ''mā''). Going tone is not split, and muddy consonants become tenuis: ''bah, pah, mah, bhah'' → ''bà, pà, mà, bà.'' Rising tone splits, not along voicing, but with muddy-consonant syllables conflating with going tone: ''baa, paa, maa, bhaa'' → ''bǎ, pǎ, mǎ, bà''. That is, ''bhaa'' and ''bhah'' are homonyms in Beijing, as indeed they are in all of Mandarin, in Wu apart from [[Wenzhounese]], in Hakka, and in reading pronunciations of Cantonese. Entering tone is likewise split in Beijing: ''mat, bhat'' → ''mà, bá''.These series are for illustration; not all of the syllables actually exist. However, the realization of entering tones in Beijing dialect, and thus in Standard Chinese, is not predictable when a syllable has a voiceless initial such as ''bat'' or ''pat''. In such cases even syllables with the same GC spelling may have different tones in Beijing, though they remain homonyms in other Mandarin dialects, such as Xian and Sichuanese.In [[Tianjin dialect]], for example, ''bat, pat, mat, bhat'' → ''bā, pā, mà, bá''. This is due to historical dialect-mixing in the Chinese capital that resulted in unavoidably idiosyncratic correspondences. In Yue, there is a straightforward split according to consonant voicing, with a postvocalic {{angbr|h}} in Yale romanization for the latter. Muddy onsets become aspirates in even and rising tones, but tenuis in going and entering tones: ''ba, pa, ma, bha'' → ''bā, pā, māh, pāh''; ''baa, paa, maa, bhaa'' → ''bá, pá, máh, páh''; ''bah, pah, mah, bhah'' → ''ba, pa, mah, bah''; ''bat, pat, mat, bhat'' → ''baat, paat, maht, baht''. In addition, there is a split in entering tone according to vowel length, with Cantonese mid-entering tone for short vowels like ''bāt, pāt''.This only affects syllables with voiceless initials in Cantonese, but affects all entering-tone syllables in [[Bobai dialect|Bobai]]. In reading pronunciations, however, rising tone syllables with muddy onsets are treated as going tone: ''bhaa'' → ''bah'' rather than → ''páh''. There is also an unpredictable split in the even ''ping yin'' tone which indicates diminutives or a change in part of speech, but this is not written in all Cantonese romanizations (it is written in Yale, but not in Jyutping). ==Sample text== Chao provided this poem as an example. {{Subspeciesbox | name = Golden trout | image = California Golden Trout.jpg | status = G1 | status_system = TNC | genus = Oncorhynchus | species = mykiss | species_link = Rainbow trout | subspecies = aguabonita | authority = (Jordan, 1892)<ref name=itis-mykiss-aguabonita>{{ITIS | id=553419 | taxon=Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita | accessdate=27 December 2013}}</ref> | range_map = KernRiverRainbowRangeMap.png | range_map_alt = | range_map_caption = Kern River trout range map }}
The '''California golden trout''', or simply the '''golden trout ''' (''Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita''), is a [[subspecies]] of the [[rainbow trout]] native to [[California]]. The golden trout is native to Golden Trout Creek (tributary to the [[Kern River]]), Volcano Creek (tributary to Golden Trout Creek), and the [[South Fork Kern River]]. It is the state fish of California.
The California golden trout is closely related to two other [[rainbow trout]] subspecies. The [[Little Kern golden trout]] (''O. m. whitei''), found in the [[Little Kern River]] basin, and the [[Kern River rainbow trout]] (''O. m. gilberti''), found in the [[Kern River]] system. Together, these three trout form what is sometimes referred to as the "golden trout complex".<ref>Inland Fishes of California, By Peter B. Moyle. Page 20.</ref>
[[File:Goldentroutwiki.jpg|Right|thumb|Golden trout from within the [[John Muir Wilderness]].]] [[File:Wind River 08 042.jpg|Right|thumb|Golden trout caught in a high mountain lake of the [[Wind River Range]].]]
==Taxonomy== Originally the golden trout was described as a subspecies of the salmon species, with a name ''Salmo mykiss agua-bonita'',<ref name=cof/> and it is still often considered a subspecies (now called ''Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita'') along with several other rainbow trout subspecies commonly known as [[redband trout]].{{citation needed|date=November 2014}}
[[FishBase]] and the [[Catalog of Fishes]] however now (2014) list ''O. aguabonita'' as an independent species rather than as subspecies of ''O. mykiss''.<ref name=cof>W. Eschmeyer (2014) [http://researcharchive.calacademy.org/research/ichthyology/catalog/fishcatget.asp?spid=10603 aguabonita, Salmo mykiss] Catalog of Fishes. California Academy of Sciences. (accessed 3 Nov 2014)</ref><ref>{{FishBase|Oncorhynchus|aguabonita|year=2014}}</ref> Likewise, while [[ITIS]] lists ''O. m. whitei'' and ''O. m. gilberti'' as subspecies of ''O. mykiss'',<ref name=itis>{{ ITIS | id=161989 | taxon=Oncorhynchus mykiss | accessdate=27 January 2013 }}</ref> ''O. aguabonita'' instead is listed as a full species.<ref name=itis-mykiss-aguabonita/><ref name=itis-aguabonita>{{ ITIS | id=161987 | taxon=Oncorhynchus aguabonita | accessdate=27 January 2013 }}</ref>
==Description== The golden trout has golden flanks with red, horizontal bands along the lateral lines on each side and about 10 dark, vertical, oval marks (called "parr marks") on each side. Dorsal, lateral and anal fins have white leading edges. In their native habitat, adults range from {{convert|6|to|12|in|cm}} long. Fish over {{convert|12|in|cm}} are considered large. Golden trout that have been transplanted to lakes have been recorded up to {{convert|11|lbs|kg}}.
The golden trout should be distinguished from the similarly named [[Rainbow trout|golden rainbow trout]], also known as the palomino trout. The golden rainbow is a color variant of the rainbow trout.<ref>S. Dobosz, K. Kohlmann, K. Goryczko, H. Kuzminski. "Growth and vitality in yellow forms of rainbow trout". ''[[Journal of Applied Ichthyology]]'', Volume 16, Issue 3 pp. 117–120, June 2000 {{doi|10.1046/j.1439-0426.2000.00147.x}}.</ref>
The golden trout is commonly found at elevations from {{convert|6890|ft|m}} to {{convert|10,000|ft|m}} above [[sea level]], and is native only to [[California]]'s southern [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] mountains. Outside of its native range in California, Golden trout are more often found in cirques and creeks in wilderness areas around 10,500–12,000"+, often beyond 12,500"+ passes that are not passable without crampons, ice axes, and ropes until after the Fourth of July.<ref name=Plan/> Their preferred water temperature is {{convert|58|to|62|F|C}} but they can tolerate temperatures in degraded streams on the Kern Plateau as high as {{convert|70|F|C}} so long as those waters cool during the night.<ref name=Plan/> The only other species of fish indigenous to the native range of California golden trout is the [[Sacramento sucker]] (''Catostomus occidentalis occidentalis'').<ref name=Pister/>
=== Record catches ===
The Wyoming Game & Fish Department state record golden trout measured {{convert|28|in|cm|abbr=on}} and weighed {{convert|11.25|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, caught in Cook Lake, Wyoming in 1948.<ref>{{cite web | title=Wyoming's Record Fish | publisher=Wyoming Game and Fish Department | url=http://wgfd.wyo.gov/web2011/FISHING-1000210.aspx | date=27 December 2013}}</ref> The [[IGFA]] "All-Tackle Length Record" for ''O. m. aguabonita'' measured {{convert|53|cm|in|abbr=on|disp=flip}} caught in Golden Lake, Wyoming in 2012.<ref>[http://wrec.igfa.org/WRecordsList.aspx?lc=AllTackleLength&cn=Trout,%20golden IGFA World Records]</ref>
== Distribution ==
''O. m. aguabonita'' is native to the southern Sierra Nevada, including the upper reach and tributaries of the South Fork of the Kern River, and Golden Trout Creek and its tributaries.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> It has been introduced in hundreds of lakes and streams outside the native range, though most of these populations did not last or hybridized with cutthroat trout and other subspecies of rainbow trout.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> Distribution data that may be incomplete or inaccurate includes the Canadian province of Alberta, and the US states of Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, New Mexico, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/>
==History== In 1892 the California golden trout was originally described by [[David Starr Jordan]], the first President of [[Stanford University]], as ''Salmo mykiss agua-bonita''. The fish was named after the Agua Bonita Waterfall where the first specimens were collected, at the mouth of Volcano Creek, at the creek's confluence with the Kern River.<ref name=Jordan>{{cite journal |title=A description of the golden trout of Kern River, California, ''Salmo mykiss agua-bonita'' |author=David Starr Jordan |journal=Proceedings of the United States National Museum |volume=xv |issue=916 |date=1892-07-24 |pages=481–483 |url=http://biostor.org/reference/14131 |accessdate=2012-10-16 |doi=10.5479/si.00963801.15-916.481}}</ref> A century later they were listed as ''Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita'' in [[Robert J. Behnke|Behnke's]] ''Native trout of western North America''.<ref>{{cite book |title=Native trout of western North America. Monograph No. 6 |authorlink=Robert J. Behnke |author=Robert J. Behnke |publisher=American Fisheries Society |year=1992 |isbn=9780913235799 |page=275 }}</ref>
In 1904 Stewart Edward White communicated to his friend President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], that overfishing could lead to extinction of the golden trout. In White's novel ''The Mountains'', he wrote about the threatened golden trout on California’s Kern Plateau. Roosevelt shared White’s concern and, through U.S. Fish Commissioner George M. Bowers, dispatched biologist [[Barton Warren Evermann]] of the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries to study the situation. In 1906 Evermann published ''The Golden Trout of the Southern High Sierras''.<ref name=Evermann>{{cite book |title= The golden trout of the southern high Sierras |authors=Barton Warren Evermann, Oliver Peebles Jenkins, Chancey Juday |publisher=Government Printing Office |year=1906 |page=51 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_golden_trout_of_the_southern_high_Si.html?id=Zds_AAAAYAAJ |accessdate=2012-10-15 }}</ref> Based on morphology, Evermann accurately described four forms of this native fish: ''Salmo roosevelti'' from Golden Trout (Volcano) Creek, ''Salmo aguabonita'' from nearby South Fork of the Kern River, ''Salmo whitei'' (named in recognition of Stewart Edward White) from the Little Kern River, and ''Salmo gilberti'', the Kern River rainbow.<ref name=Pister>{{cite journal |title=California Golden Trout: Perspectives on Restoration and Management |author=Edwin Philip Pister |journal=Fisheries |volume=35 |number=11 |pages=550–553 |doi=10.1577/1548-8446-35.11.550|year=2010 }}</ref>
Genetic studies have since clarified three groups of trout native to the Kern River: California golden trout (''O. m. aguabonita'') native to the South Fork Kern River and Golden Trout Creek (tributary to the Kern River mainstem but the historic course of the South Fork Kern River and now only separated from it by a lava flow and ridge of sediment), Little Kern River golden trout (''O. m. whitei''), and Kern River rainbow trout (''O. m. gilberti'').<ref>{{Cite thesis|title=Systematics, genetics and conservation of golden trout. Ph.D. dissertation. |author=Molly R. Stephens |publisher=University of California Davis |date=2007 |url=http://genome-lab.ucdavis.edu/people/Stephens/Dissertation_Stephens_FINAL_hiqual.pdf |accessdate=2012-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514211638/http://genome-lab.ucdavis.edu/people/Stephens/Dissertation_Stephens_FINAL_hiqual.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-14 |df= }}</ref>
==Conservation== Years of [[overfishing|overexploitation]], mismanagement and competition with [[introduced species|exotic species]] have brought golden trout to the brink of being designated as "[[Threatened species|threatened]]".{{citation needed | reason=Designated by whom? Which subspecies? Circumstances of "brink" of designation? | date=December 2013}} Introduced [[brook trout]] (''Salvelinus fontinalis'') outcompete them for food, introduced [[brown trout]] (''Salmo trutta'') prey on them and introduced rainbow trout (''O. mykiss'') hybridize with them, damaging the native gene pool through [[introgression]]. Populations have been in steady decline for decades.
In 1978 the [[Golden Trout Wilderness]] was established within [[Inyo National Forest]] and [[Sequoia National Forest]], protecting the upper watersheds of the Kern River and South Fork Kern River.
In September 2004, the [[California Department of Fish and Game]] signed an agreement with federal agencies to work on restoring back-country habitat, heavily damaged by overgrazing from cattle and sheep, as part of a comprehensive conservation strategy.<ref name=Plan>{{cite report |title=Conservation Assessment and Strategy for the California Golden Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita) Tulare County, California |authors=Stanley J. Stephens, Christy McGuire, Lisa Sims |publisher=California Department of Fish and Game |date=2004-09-17 |url=http://www.tucalifornia.org/cgtic/GTCAssessmnt&Strategy9-04.pdf |accessdate=2012-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719005821/http://www.tucalifornia.org/cgtic/GTCAssessmnt%26Strategy9-04.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref>
The [[Endangered Species Act|US Endangered Species Act]] (USESA) designated the subspecies ''O. m. whitei'' as LT, or Listed Threatened, since 1978, under the name ''Oncorhynchus aguabonita whitei''.<ref name=natureserve-whitei/>
===Subspecies designations=== [[NatureServe]] has designated the following [[NatureServe Conservation Status]] for the three subspecies:
* [[Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita|''Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita''—Golden trout]] (G5T1): [[Critically endangered|Critically Imperiled]], last reviewed in 2013.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita>{{cite web | title=Comprehensive Report Species – Oncorhynchus mykiss aguabonita | url=http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?searchName=Oncorhynchus+mykiss+aguabonita | website=NatureServe Explorer | publisher=NatureServe Inc. | accessdate=27 December 2013 | last=Hammerson | first=G | year=2013}}</ref> The primary threat is hybridization and introgression with stocked rainbow trout.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> Other threats include competition with non-native brown trout and rainbow trout, predation by brown trout, habitat degradation from cattle grazing, and possibly expanding beaver populations in the native range.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> Genetic studies showed hybridization with stocked rainbow trout in almost all known wild populations analyzed to as of 2003.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> Non-hybridized populations are restricted to less than 1% of their native range, and confinement to these areas for long periods create a significant risk of inbreeding depression, and loss of heterozygosity and genetic variance.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/> * [[Kern River rainbow trout|''Oncorhynchus mykiss gilberti''—Kern River rainbow trout]] (G5T1Q): [[Critically endangered|Critically Imperiled]], with questionable taxonomy that may reduce conservation priority, last reviewed in 2005.<ref name=natureserve-gilberti>{{cite web | title=Comprehensive Report Species – Oncorhynchus mykiss gilberti | url=http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?searchName=Oncorhynchus+mykiss+gilberti | website=NatureServe Explorer | publisher=NatureServe Inc. | accessdate=27 December 2013 | last1=Hopkins | first1=T | last2=Moyle | first2=P | last3=Hammerson | first3=G | year=2005}}</ref> Few if any genetically pure populations still exist. Primary threats include continued introgression with introduced rainbow trout, habitat loss from grazing, logging and road building, unpredictable events such as floods, drought, and fire (and subsequent landslides), and reduced habitat availability due to introduced beaver.<ref name=natureserve-gilberti/> * [[Little Kern golden trout|''Oncorhynchus mykiss whitei''—Little Kern golden trout]] (G5T2Q): [[Endangered species|Imperiled]], with questionable taxonomy that may reduce conservation priority, last reviewed in 2005.<ref name=natureserve-whitei>{{cite web | title=Comprehensive Report Species – Oncorhynchus mykiss whitei | url=http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?searchName=Oncorhynchus+mykiss+whitei | website=NatureServe Explorer | publisher=NatureServe Inc. | accessdate=27 December 2013 | last1=Hopkins | first1=T | last2=Moyle | first2=P | last3=Hammerson | first3=G | year=2005}}</ref> Hybridization with introduced rainbow trout is considered a threat, and "there is a constant threat from introductions of other salmonids by disgruntled anglers."<ref name=natureserve-whitei/> The subspecies still occurs in the Little Kern River, above the falls on the lower river, though some populations show signs of introgression with coastal rainbow trout.<ref name=natureserve-whitei/>
The American Fisheries Society has designated all three subspecies as [[Threatened species|Threatened]] since August 2008.<ref name=natureserve-aguabonita/><ref name=natureserve-whitei/><ref name=natureserve-gilberti/>
==Translocations outside of endemic range== For sportfishing, the California golden trout underwent many twentieth century translocations into multiple Western states and established populations survive in California, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Washington, Colorado, and Wyoming. Populations in the high-elevation lakes in the [[Ruby Mountains]], Nevada, have died out.<ref name=NAS>{{cite web |title=''Oncorhynchus aguabonita'' (Golden Trout) |author=Pam Fuller and Matt Neilson |publisher=USGS Nonindigenous aquatic species (NAS) database |date=2012-03-29 |url=https://nas.er.usgs.gov/queries/factsheet.aspx?SpeciesID=889 |accessdate=2012-10-14 }}</ref> The current status in other states where the California golden trout were planted (Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico and Oregon) lacks documentation.
==Chuck Yeager and the New Mexico population== When [[Colonel]] [[Chuck Yeager]] introduced one of his commanding officers, [[General]] Irving "Twig" Branch, to the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] populations of golden trout, Branch ordered Yeager and [[Clarence E. Anderson|Bud Anderson]] to introduce the species to the mountain streams of [[New Mexico]].<ref name="yeagerbio_348-351">[[Chuck Yeager|Yeager, Chuck]] and [[Leo Janos|Janos, Leo]]. ''Yeager: An Autobiography''. Pages 348-351 (paperback). New York: Bantam Books, 1986. {{ISBN|0-553-25674-2}}.</ref> However, the New Mexico populations have also died out.<ref name=NAS/>
In his second autobiography, ''Press On'', Yeager details his annual fishing trips to catch golden trout which he extols as one of the best game fish and best eating fish to be found.
